column20: 'DM_Notes'
'TEXT'

'(CFPR)
+5 plate mail that will cause the wearer and everything non-living thing he or she is wearing or carrying to become æthereal when the command word is spoken. Every time the wearer becomes æthereal
column21: a charge is used. The plate mail holds 20 charges and every 5 uses reduces the AC bonus by 1. Therefore
column22: five uses of a fully charged plate mail of ætherealiality reduces the AC bonus to +4
column23: but note the AC bonus is always at least +1
column24: even if all charges are expended. This magical armour cannot be recharged by any means.'

column22:
'(CDFPR)
This shield grants +1 to AC against melee weapons but a +4 AC bonus vs missiles or hurled weapons. The shield also grants a 20% magic resistance against magic missiles provided
column23: of course
column24: the magic missile attack originates from in front of the wielder of the shield.'

column21: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column22:
th{padding: 3px}(AFPRT)
A +3 arrow particularly deadly to a certain type of creature. There is always some mark
column23: usually a rune or pictograph
column24:
to denote the type of target the arrow will instantly slay on a successful attack. A chart is included for random determination but the GM is advised to modify the chart to fit his or her unique milieu. One should note the type can be as general as “humanoid’ or as specific as “hobgoblin.”
d%Result
01-02Clerics
03-04Demi-Humans
05-06Demons
07-08Devils
09-10Dinosaurs
11-12Dragons
13-14Druids
15-16Dwarfs
17-18Elementals
19-20Elves
21-22Ettin
23-24Fighters
25-26Ghouls
27-28Giants
29-30Gnolls
31-32Gnomes
33-34Goblins
35-36Golems
37-38Griffons
39-40Halflings
41-42Harpies
43-44Hell Hounds
45-46Hippogriffs
47-48Hobgoblins
49-50Humanoids
51-52Humans
53-54Hydras
55-56Illusionists
57-58Kobolds
59-60Liches
61-62Lizard Men
63-64Lycanthropes
65-66Magic Users
67-68Mammals
69-70Medusae
71-72Mummies
73-74Naga
75-76Ogres
77-78Orcs
79-80Paladins
81-82Rangers
83-84Reptiles
85-86Skeletons
87-88Spiders
89-90Thieves
91-92Troglodytes
93-94Trolls
95-96Undead
97-98Vampires
99-00Zombies
'

column20:
'(AFPR)
A +2 magic hand axe specially made for throwing up to 60 ft and retaining both its to hit and damage bonus when used as a missile weapon.'

column21:
'(AFPRT)
Besides a +3 bonus on to hit and damage rolls
column22: all attacks with this weapon are considered short range. 10% of these weapons are heavy crossbows.'

column21:
'(AFPRT)
This +1 crossbow has double the range in all categories of standard crossbows. 20% of these weapons are heavy crossbows.'

'(AFPRT)
This weapon allows double the normal firing rate of normal crossbows. When determining randomly
column22: 10% of these weapons are heavy crossbows.'

'(AFPRT)
Besides a +3 bonus on to hit and damage rolls
column23: all attacks with this weapon are considered short range. 10% of these weapons are heavy crossbows.'

column20:
'(AFT)
A +1 dagger which
column21: on a natural hit roll of 20
column22: injects a dose of lethal poison into its victim
column23: Treasure though the target gets a saving throw vs poison to negate. The dagger can hold six doses of poison in a tiny compartment in the hilt and can be refilled. Use of this weapon by good aligned characters should be closely monitored.'

'(F)
Usually functions as a +2 hammer. In the hands of a dwarfish fighter who knows the command word
column24: however
column25: this weapon is a full +3 warhammer. The hammer of the dwarfs retains its attack bonus when hurled as a missile weapon
column26: doing double damage if it hits and boomeranging back to its owner. If thrown at a giant opponent (including ogres
column27: trolls
column28: and ettin) the hammer will cause triple damage if it hits.'

column23:
'(F)
Usually functions as a +2 hammer. In the hands of a dwarfish fighter who knows the command word
column24: however
column25: this weapon is a full +3 warhammer. The hammer of the dwarfs retains its attack bonus when hurled as a missile weapon
column26: doing double damage if it hits and boomeranging back to its owner. If thrown at a giant opponent (including ogres
column27: trolls
column28: and ettin) the hammer will cause triple damage if it hits.'

column22:
'(CFPR)
A +1 mace with special powers vs evil creatures and the undead. The mace has a neutral good alignment and does 5d4 points of bonus damage to any evil target it strikes. Against the undead
column23: however
column24: the holy mace reveals its true power. When the mace strikes a demon
column25: devil
column26: or undead creature
column27: a turn undead roll is made on the Turning Undead table as the wielder were a 12th level cleric. If the creature fails its roll it is immediately blasted out of existence by the holy power of the mace. Some creatures (example: skeletons
column28: zombies
column29: and ghouls) are automatically destroyed. Stronger undead creatures which have a numerical result instead of a “T” or “D” on the matrix get that number as a saving throw vs disruption. Even if the undead target makes its saving throw or is immune to disruption
column30: the mace will still deal double the damage plus double the damage bonus.'

column22:
'(CFPR)
A +1 mace with special powers vs evil creatures and the undead. The mace has a neutral good alignment and does 5d4 points of bonus damage to any evil target it strikes. Against the undead
column23: however
column24: the holy mace reveals its true power. When the mace strikes a demon
column25: devil
column26: or undead creature
column27: a turn undead roll is made on the Turning Undead table as the wielder were a 12th level cleric. If the creature fails its roll it is immediately blasted out of existence by the holy power of the mace. Some creatures (example: skeletons
column28: zombies
column29: and ghouls) are automatically destroyed. Stronger undead creatures which have a numerical result instead of a “T” or “D” on the matrix get that number as a saving throw vs disruption. Even if the undead target makes its saving throw or is immune to disruption
column30: the mace will still deal double the damage plus double the damage bonus.'

column20:
'(AFPRT)
A shorter than normal trident with a 6 ft haft
column21: usable as a melee or missile weapon but too short in this mode to be set against a charge. When the command word is spoken
column22: the trident lengthens into a full pole arm and can be set against a charge as a normal pole arm. In either mode
column23: the weapon is +3 to hit and damage.'

column21:
'(AFPRT)
Grants +2 “to hit” and damage rolls
column22: but is figured as a +1 weapon in terms of which creatures it can affect.'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
A feared weapon
column24: the bleeding sword is a +1 blade with a terrible power. Any damage caused by this weapon is progressive for up to 10 melee rounds on a 1 for 1 basis. An attack causing 5 points of damage
column25: for instance
column26: will cause an additional 5 points of damage the next combat round and each following round; up to 50 damage points total. Hit point damage can be halted by the victim leaving combat and binding his or her wounds. All hits from this blade do damage the same way. Wounds caused by this magic sword can only be healed with rest and time; no curative magic of any type will be effective. Even creatures capable of regenerating cannot heal themselves thus
column27: whether this a natural ability (trolls) or magical ability (ring of regeneration).'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
An unusual weapon. During the first round the dancing sword is used in combat it performs as a +1 blade. Each subsequent round the sword adds an additional +1 bonus up to the maximum of +4 in the fourth round. In round 5 the process begins again
column24:
and at this point the blade can “dance”.

A dancing sword can then be loosed from the wielder’s hand to fight on its own for 4 rounds
column25: up to 30 ft away. The dancing sword will fight as if still being held by the owner and gains the successive bonuses to its attack and damage each round. When the dancing sword cycles from +4 back to +1 it will return to its owner’s hand
column26:
where it must be wielded for 4 rounds before being released to dance again.

If the owner declines to grasp the sword when it returns to him or her
column27: or if he or she moves more than 30 ft away from the dancing sword
column28: the weapon will fall inanimate to the ground. The sword cannot be physically attacked by its opponent while dancing
column29: though it is subject to magical attacks and effects (examples: fireball
column30: transmute metal to wood). While the sword is dancing
column31: the wielder can perform any other action he or she wishes

column23:
'(AFPRT)
This sword is +4
column24: but the wielder of this sword has the option each round of adding all or part of the bonus to his or her AC. Thus
column25: a fighter could increase his or her current AC of 2 (plate mail with shield) to AC 0 by deducting 2 points from the sword’s +4 bonus and making the defender> +2 to hit for that round. '

column23: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column24:
th{padding: 3px}(AFPRT)
The dragonbane sword is +2 against most opponents
column25: +4 vs all dragons and against one specific type of dragon (determined randomly) deals triple damage. If one of these swords should be determined to be intelligent (see below)
column26: it will in no way allow the player to slay a dragon of the same alignment. A chart is included to assist the GM with selecting a dragon type for triple damage. Since a campaign may include other types of dragons
column27:
the GM may wish to modify this list.
d10Result
01black
02blue
03brass
04bronze
05copper
06gold
07green
08red
09silver
10white
'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
The blade of this weapon bursts into flame when its command word is spoken
column24: giving illumination as a torch. The sword does not otherwise glow as most other magic swords do. The flame tongue’s fiery blade can easily ignite paper
column25: oil
column26: kindling
column27: webs
column28:
or dry wood.
The sword is normally +1
column29: but gives a +2 as a trollbane does
column30: a +3 bonus against creatures that are inflammable
column31: bird-like or have a special attack involving cold
column32: and a +4 against undead. These bonuses do not stack; only the highest bonus should be counted. (Thus
column34: the sword is +4 not +7.)'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
The frost brand is normally +3
column24: granting a +6 bonus against any creature using fire as its attack (e.g. red dragons) or dwelling in fire such as fire elementals. This weapon grants special defence against fire; treat the wielder as if he or she were wearing a ring of fire resistance. The cold based magic of the blade also has a 50% chance of extinguishing fire for a 10 ft radius
column25: including magical fires such as a wall of fire but not fire based attacks such as hell hound breath attacks or fireballs. Note: this blade does not shed light when drawn unless the ambient temperature is below freezing.'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
This sword will be +2 when fighting most foes. Against giant-like humanoids such as ettin or ogres
column24: the giant slayer functions as a +3 blade. Against true giants such as hill giants or storm giants
column25: the sword also does double damage.'

column23:
'(P)
In the hands of anyone but a paladin
column24: this is a + 2 weapon in every way
column25: with no additional features. In the hands of a paladin the true power of this holy weapon is revealed
column26: acting as +5. The holy sword will also inflict +10 damage against all chaotic evil opponents
column27: dispel magic with a 5 ft radius as if the paladin were casting the spell as a magic user equal to his or her own experience level
column28: and create 50% magic resistance in a 5 ft radius on command. Note the +10 damage bonus is instead of

column23: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column24:
th{padding: 3px}(AFPRT)
This is a +1 blade regarding to hit and damage bonuses
column25: but the keenblade is a +3 weapon for purposes of determining who or what it can hit. When wielded in combat and a high to hit roll is thrown
column26: this powerful blade will sever a random extremity or appendage
column27: including the neck/head. When used in combat
column28: the GM should assign a value to each extremity and dice the result randomly. A lizard man
column30: would have six extremities and a successful hit to sever could be resolved by assigning a value of 1 to the neck
column31: 2 to the left arm
column34: 5 to the right leg
column35:
and 6 to the tail; then rolling 1d6 and observing the result.

When using the keenblade in combat
column36:
the chances of severing some appendage are as follows:
Opponent isNatural (unadjusted) “to hit” roll
Man-sized or smaller18-20
Large19-20
Solid metal or solid stone20


The keenblade is an exception to the glowing magic sword rule. The wielder of the sword can decide whether the blade will shed no light at all
column37: dim light in a 5 ft radius circle
column38: light in a 15 ft circle
column39: or a bright light as a light spell with a 30 ft radius.'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
In addition to +1 to AC and damage
column24: the luck blade also grants its wielder +1 to all saving throws. Additionally
column25: the luck blade grants 1d4+1 wishes
column26: though the blade does nothing to communicate the number of wishes it holds to its owner.'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
This weapon will always function as at least a +1 sword. When fighting against magic users
column24: spell-casting monsters
column25: monsters with spell-like abilities
column26: gated or extra-planar creatures
column27: conjured monsters
column28: or summoned monsters
column29: the sword will be +2 to hit and damage. Note that a non-magical creature which is granted spell casting powers by artificial means
column30: a human fighter wearing a ring of spell storing for example
column31: does not qualify as magic-using.'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
This weapon is +2. On a “to hit” roll of natural 20 the nine lives stealer will draw the life force from its target
column24: slaying it instantly. This ability can be used 9 times before it is lost forever
column25: though the sword will retain its +2 bonus thereafter. The victim is allowed a saving throw vs magic and
column26: if successful
column27: there is no effect and the sword does not expend a charge.'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
This weapon is normally +1
column24: but gives a +3 bonus against creatures that regenerate hit points
column25: including those that do so by magical means such as a ring of regeneration.'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
This +2 sword allows the wielder to drain life force from the target. When a natural 20 is rolled the target loses a level of experience along with the appropriate hit die and abilities
column24: as if he or she had been struck by an undead creature such as a wraith. The absorbed hit points will cure any damage the wielder of the sword has sustained
column25: up to his or her normal hit point total.'

column23: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column24:
th{padding: 3px}(AFPRT)
An even deadlier variant of the keenblade
column25: the vorpal blade is a +3 weapon and on a high attack roll will always decapitate its target. (Not all opponents have heads
column26: nor is every opponent necessarily slain by decapitation.) To determine the chance of this
column27:
consult the table below.
Opponent is:Natural (unadjusted) “to hit” roll
Man-sized or smaller17-20
Large18-20
Solid metal or solid stone20
'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
This weapon is normally +1
column24: but gives a +2 bonus against: were-creatures
column25: any creature capable of assuming another creature’s form (such as druids or vampires)
column26: or a creature which has been polymorphed or shape changed.'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
The sword is normally +1
column24: but gives a +4 against any reptile including but not limited to: dinosaurs
column25: dragons
column26: hydras
column27: lizards
column28: lizard men

column22:
'(AFPRT)
This is an intelligent sword.'

A dancing sword can then be loosed from the wielder’s hand to fight on its own for 4 rounds
column25: up to 30 ft away. The dancing sword will fight as if still being held by the owner and gains the successive bonuses to its attack and damage each round. When the dancing sword cycles from +4 back to +1 it will return to its owner’s hand
column26:
where it must be wielded for 4 rounds before being released to dance again.

If the owner declines to grasp the sword when it returns to him or her
column27: or if he or she moves more than 30 ft away from the dancing sword
column28: the weapon will fall inanimate to the ground. The sword cannot be physically attacked by its opponent while dancing
column29: though it is subject to magical attacks and effects (examples: fireball
column30: transmute metal to wood). While the sword is dancing
column31: the wielder can perform any other action he or she wishes

column23:
'(AFPRT)
This sword is +4
column24: but the wielder of this sword has the option each round of adding all or part of the bonus to his or her AC. Thus
column25: a fighter could increase his or her current AC of 2 (plate mail with shield) to AC 0 by deducting 2 points from the sword’s +4 bonus and making the defender> +2 to hit for that round. '

column23: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column24:
th{padding: 3px}(AFPRT)
The dragonbane sword is +2 against most opponents
column25: +4 vs all dragons and against one specific type of dragon (determined randomly) deals triple damage. If one of these swords should be determined to be intelligent (see below)
column26: it will in no way allow the player to slay a dragon of the same alignment. A chart is included to assist the GM with selecting a dragon type for triple damage. Since a campaign may include other types of dragons
column27:
the GM may wish to modify this list.
d10Result
01black
02blue
03brass
04bronze
05copper
06gold
07green
08red
09silver
10white
'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
The blade of this weapon bursts into flame when its command word is spoken
column24: giving illumination as a torch. The sword does not otherwise glow as most other magic swords do. The flame tongue’s fiery blade can easily ignite paper
column25: oil
column26: kindling
column27: webs
column28:
or dry wood.
The sword is normally +1
column29: but gives a +2 as a trollbane does
column30: a +3 bonus against creatures that are inflammable
column31: bird-like or have a special attack involving cold
column32: and a +4 against undead. These bonuses do not stack; only the highest bonus should be counted. (Thus
column34: the sword is +4 not +7.)'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
The frost brand is normally +3
column24: granting a +6 bonus against any creature using fire as its attack (e.g. red dragons) or dwelling in fire such as fire elementals. This weapon grants special defence against fire; treat the wielder as if he or she were wearing a ring of fire resistance. The cold based magic of the blade also has a 50% chance of extinguishing fire for a 10 ft radius
column25: including magical fires such as a wall of fire but not fire based attacks such as hell hound breath attacks or fireballs. Note: this blade does not shed light when drawn unless the ambient temperature is below freezing.'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
This sword will be +2 when fighting most foes. Against giant-like humanoids such as ettin or ogres
column24: the giant slayer functions as a +3 blade. Against true giants such as hill giants or storm giants
column25: the sword also does double damage.'

column23:
'(P)
In the hands of anyone but a paladin
column24: this is a + 2 weapon in every way
column25: with no additional features. In the hands of a paladin the true power of this holy weapon is revealed
column26: acting as +5. The holy sword will also inflict +10 damage against all chaotic evil opponents
column27: dispel magic with a 5 ft radius as if the paladin were casting the spell as a magic user equal to his or her own experience level
column28: and create 50% magic resistance in a 5 ft radius on command. Note the +10 damage bonus is instead of

column23: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column24:
th{padding: 3px}(AFPRT)
This is a +1 blade regarding to hit and damage bonuses
column25: but the keenblade is a +3 weapon for purposes of determining who or what it can hit. When wielded in combat and a high to hit roll is thrown
column26: this powerful blade will sever a random extremity or appendage
column27: including the neck/head. When used in combat
column28: the GM should assign a value to each extremity and dice the result randomly. A lizard man
column30: would have six extremities and a successful hit to sever could be resolved by assigning a value of 1 to the neck
column31: 2 to the left arm
column34: 5 to the right leg
column35:
and 6 to the tail; then rolling 1d6 and observing the result.

When using the keenblade in combat
column36:
the chances of severing some appendage are as follows:
Opponent isNatural (unadjusted) “to hit” roll
Man-sized or smaller18-20
Large19-20
Solid metal or solid stone20


The keenblade is an exception to the glowing magic sword rule. The wielder of the sword can decide whether the blade will shed no light at all
column37: dim light in a 5 ft radius circle
column38: light in a 15 ft circle
column39: or a bright light as a light spell with a 30 ft radius.'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
In addition to +1 to AC and damage
column24: the luck blade also grants its wielder +1 to all saving throws. Additionally
column25: the luck blade grants 1d4+1 wishes
column26: though the blade does nothing to communicate the number of wishes it holds to its owner.'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
This weapon will always function as at least a +1 sword. When fighting against magic users
column24: spell-casting monsters
column25: monsters with spell-like abilities
column26: gated or extra-planar creatures
column27: conjured monsters
column28: or summoned monsters
column29: the sword will be +2 to hit and damage. Note that a non-magical creature which is granted spell casting powers by artificial means
column30: a human fighter wearing a ring of spell storing for example
column31: does not qualify as magic-using.'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
This weapon is +2. On a “to hit” roll of natural 20 the nine lives stealer will draw the life force from its target
column24: slaying it instantly. This ability can be used 9 times before it is lost forever
column25: though the sword will retain its +2 bonus thereafter. The victim is allowed a saving throw vs magic and
column26: if successful
column27: there is no effect and the sword does not expend a charge.'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
This weapon is normally +1
column24: but gives a +3 bonus against creatures that regenerate hit points
column25: including those that do so by magical means such as a ring of regeneration.'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
This +2 sword allows the wielder to drain life force from the target. When a natural 20 is rolled the target loses a level of experience along with the appropriate hit die and abilities
column24: as if he or she had been struck by an undead creature such as a wraith. The absorbed hit points will cure any damage the wielder of the sword has sustained
column25: up to his or her normal hit point total.'

column23: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column24:
th{padding: 3px}(AFPRT)
An even deadlier variant of the keenblade
column25: the vorpal blade is a +3 weapon and on a high attack roll will always decapitate its target. (Not all opponents have heads
column26: nor is every opponent necessarily slain by decapitation.) To determine the chance of this
column27:
consult the table below.
Opponent is:Natural (unadjusted) “to hit” roll
Man-sized or smaller17-20
Large18-20
Solid metal or solid stone20
'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
This weapon is normally +1
column24: but gives a +2 bonus against: were-creatures
column25: any creature capable of assuming another creature’s form (such as druids or vampires)
column26: or a creature which has been polymorphed or shape changed.'

column23:
'(AFPRT)
The sword is normally +1
column24: but gives a +4 against any reptile including but not limited to: dinosaurs
column25: dragons
column26: hydras
column27: lizards
column28: lizard men

column22:
'(AFPRT)
This is an intelligent sword.'

'(AFPRT)
A feared weapon
column23: the bleeding sword is a +1 blade with a terrible power. Any damage caused by this weapon is progressive for up to 10 melee rounds on a 1 for 1 basis. An attack causing 5 points of damage
column24: for instance
column25: will cause an additional 5 points of damage the next combat round and each following round; up to 50 damage points total. Hit point damage can be halted by the victim leaving combat and binding his or her wounds. All hits from this blade do damage the same way. Wounds caused by this magic sword can only be healed with rest and time; no curative magic of any type will be effective. Even creatures capable of regenerating cannot heal themselves thus
column26: whether this a natural ability (trolls) or magical ability (ring of regeneration).'

column22:
'(AFPRT)
An unusual weapon. During the first round the dancing sword is used in combat it performs as a +1 blade. Each subsequent round the sword adds an additional +1 bonus up to the maximum of +4 in the fourth round. In round 5 the process begins again
column23:
and at this point the blade can “dance”.

A dancing sword can then be loosed from the wielder’s hand to fight on its own for 4 rounds
column24: up to 30 ft away. The dancing sword will fight as if still being held by the owner and gains the successive bonuses to its attack and damage each round. When the dancing sword cycles from +4 back to +1 it will return to its owner’s hand
column25:
where it must be wielded for 4 rounds before being released to dance again.

If the owner declines to grasp the sword when it returns to him or her
column26: or if he or she moves more than 30 ft away from the dancing sword
column27: the weapon will fall inanimate to the ground. The sword cannot be physically attacked by its opponent while dancing
column28: though it is subject to magical attacks and effects (examples: fireball
column29: transmute metal to wood). While the sword is dancing
column30: the wielder can perform any other action he or she wishes
column31: including fighting with another weapon.'

th{padding: 3px}(AFPRT)
The dragonbane sword is +2 against most opponents
column24: +4 vs all dragons and against one specific type of dragon (determined randomly) deals triple damage. If one of these swords should be determined to be intelligent (see below)
column25: it will in no way allow the player to slay a dragon of the same alignment. A chart is included to assist the GM with selecting a dragon type for triple damage. Since a campaign may include other types of dragons
column26:
the GM may wish to modify this list.
d10Result
01black
02blue
03brass
04bronze
05copper
06gold
07green
08red
09silver
10white
'

column22:
'(AFPRT)
The blade of this weapon bursts into flame when its command word is spoken
column23: giving illumination as a torch. The sword does not otherwise glow as most other magic swords do. The flame tongue’s fiery blade can easily ignite paper
column24: oil
column25: kindling
column26: webs
column27:
or dry wood.
The sword is normally +1
column28: but gives a +2 as a trollbane does
column29: a +3 bonus against creatures that are inflammable
column30: bird-like or have a special attack involving cold
column31: and a +4 against undead. These bonuses do not stack; only the highest bonus should be counted. (Thus

column22:
'(AFPRT)
The frost brand is normally +3
column23: granting a +6 bonus against any creature using fire as its attack (e.g. red dragons) or dwelling in fire such as fire elementals. This weapon grants special defence against fire; treat the wielder as if he or she were wearing a ring of fire resistance. The cold based magic of the blade also has a 50% chance of extinguishing fire for a 10 ft radius
column24: including magical fires such as a wall of fire but not fire based attacks such as hell hound breath attacks or fireballs. Note: this blade does not shed light when drawn unless the ambient temperature is below freezing.'

column22:
'(AFPRT)
This sword will be +2 when fighting most foes. Against giant-like humanoids such as ettin or ogres
column23: the giant slayer functions as a +3 blade. Against true giants such as hill giants or storm giants
column24: the sword also does double damage.'

column22:
'(P)
In the hands of anyone but a paladin
column23: this is a + 2 weapon in every way
column24: with no additional features. In the hands of a paladin the true power of this holy weapon is revealed
column25: acting as +5. The holy sword will also inflict +10 damage against all chaotic evil opponents
column26: dispel magic with a 5 ft radius as if the paladin were casting the spell as a magic user equal to his or her own experience level
column27: and create 50% magic resistance in a 5 ft radius on command. Note the +10 damage bonus is instead of
column28: not in addition to

column22: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column23:
th{padding: 3px}(AFPRT)
This is a +1 blade regarding to hit and damage bonuses
column24: but the keenblade is a +3 weapon for purposes of determining who or what it can hit. When wielded in combat and a high to hit roll is thrown
column25: this powerful blade will sever a random extremity or appendage
column26: including the neck/head. When used in combat
column27: the GM should assign a value to each extremity and dice the result randomly. A lizard man
column28: for example
column29: would have six extremities and a successful hit to sever could be resolved by assigning a value of 1 to the neck
column31: 3 to the right arm
column34:
and 6 to the tail; then rolling 1d6 and observing the result.

When using the keenblade in combat
column35:
the chances of severing some appendage are as follows:
Opponent isNatural (unadjusted) “to hit” roll
Man-sized or smaller18-20
Large19-20
Solid metal or solid stone20


The keenblade is an exception to the glowing magic sword rule. The wielder of the sword can decide whether the blade will shed no light at all
column36: dim light in a 5 ft radius circle
column37: light in a 15 ft circle
column38: or a bright light as a light spell with a 30 ft radius.'

column22:
'(AFPRT)
In addition to +1 to AC and damage
column23: the luck blade also grants its wielder +1 to all saving throws. Additionally
column24: the luck blade grants 1d4+1 wishes
column25: though the blade does nothing to communicate the number of wishes it holds to its owner.'

column22:
'(AFPRT)
This weapon will always function as at least a +1 sword. When fighting against magic users
column23: spell-casting monsters
column24: monsters with spell-like abilities
column25: gated or extra-planar creatures
column26: conjured monsters
column27: or summoned monsters
column28: the sword will be +2 to hit and damage. Note that a non-magical creature which is granted spell casting powers by artificial means
column29: a human fighter wearing a ring of spell storing for example

column22:
'(AFPRT)
This weapon is +2. On a “to hit” roll of natural 20 the nine lives stealer will draw the life force from its target
column23: slaying it instantly. This ability can be used 9 times before it is lost forever
column24: though the sword will retain its +2 bonus thereafter. The victim is allowed a saving throw vs magic and
column25: if successful
column26: there is no effect and the sword does not expend a charge.'

column22:
'(AFPRT)
This weapon is normally +1
column23: but gives a +3 bonus against creatures that regenerate hit points
column24: including those that do so by magical means such as a ring of regeneration.'

column22:
'(AFPRT)
This +2 sword allows the wielder to drain life force from the target. When a natural 20 is rolled the target loses a level of experience along with the appropriate hit die and abilities
column23: as if he or she had been struck by an undead creature such as a wraith. The absorbed hit points will cure any damage the wielder of the sword has sustained
column24: up to his or her normal hit point total.'

column22: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column23:
th{padding: 3px}(AFPRT)
An even deadlier variant of the keenblade
column24: the vorpal blade is a +3 weapon and on a high attack roll will always decapitate its target. (Not all opponents have heads
column25: nor is every opponent necessarily slain by decapitation.) To determine the chance of this
column26:
consult the table below.
Opponent is:Natural (unadjusted) “to hit” roll
Man-sized or smaller17-20
Large18-20
Solid metal or solid stone20
'

column22:
'(AFPRT)
This weapon is normally +1
column23: but gives a +2 bonus against: were-creatures
column24: any creature capable of assuming another creature’s form (such as druids or vampires)
column25: or a creature which has been polymorphed or shape changed.'

column22:
'(AFPRT)
The sword is normally +1
column23: but gives a +4 against any reptile including but not limited to: dinosaurs
column24: dragons
column25: hydras
column26: lizards
column27: lizard men
column28: snakes

column21:
'(AFPRT)
This is an intelligent sword.'

column21:
th{padding: 3px}(any)
Anyone taking this potion gains the ability to relate to
column22: understand
column23: and manipulate the emotions of a particular type of animal. The type of animal is determined by a die roll (see below)
column24: and the number of animals affected depends on the size of the animal. The following general sizes and quantities apply: wolf size or smaller
column25: 5d4; up to human size
column26: 3d4; animals up to 1
column27: 000 lbs
column28:
1d4.
d20Result
1-4Avian
5-7Fish
8-11Mammal
column31:
and fish20All listed above

Note that unless the drinker of this potion has some other means of directly communicating with the animals influenced by the potion
column32: only general emotions or inclinations may be manipulated. Humanoids are unaffected by this potion
column33: and any creature with low intelligence (5) or higher may make a saving throw to resist its effects.'

column20:
'(any)
This potion lasts for 2 turns and grants the drinker the spell-like ability to hear as the similarly named third level magic user spell. This effect can be used further to hear what is happening out of sight within 30 ft.'

'(any)
This potion lasts for 1 turn and grants the drinker the spell-like ability of clairvoyance like the third level magic user spell. Unlike the spell
column21: this potion grants the ability to see what is happening outside of the known area within 30 ft.'

column20: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column21:
th{padding: 3px}(any)
This potion lasts for 1 turn + 5d5 rounds
column22: during which time the drinker gains the ability to climb like a thief with 99% ability (a roll of 00 means failure). However
column23: the odds of failure increase by 1% for every 1
column24: 000 gp worth of weight carried. Furthermore
column25:
the type of armour worn will influence climbing ability by decreasing the percentage chance of success as follows:
-1%Any type of magical armour
-1%Studded leather
-2%Ring mail
-4%Scale mail
-7%Chain mail
-8%Banded and splinted armour
-10%Plate mail
'

column20:
'(any)
This potion is cursed
column21: yo!'

column20:
'(any)
This potion is aptly named
column21: for it convinces the drinker that the potion is of another type. If more than one person tastes this potion
column22: there is a 90% chance they all will believe the potion to be of the same type. For example
column23: a potion of clairaudience might convince the drinker there are sounds in the distance that do not truly exist.'

column20:
'(any)
This potion lasts for 1d4+7 turns. When drunk
column21: the imbiber and everything carried will shrink to 5% of the person’s original size. If only half of the potion is consumed
column22: it will shrink the imbiber 50% of his or her original size.'

column22:
th{padding: 3px}(any)
Drinking this potion grants the imbiber power equivalent to charm monster upon a dragon of a type determined by the table below. Each potion affects only one type of dragon unless otherwise indicated. The imbiber is able to control a dragon within 60 ft for the duration of 5d4 rounds. Roll on the table below for the specific type of dragon control potion.

3-4Blue dragon control
5-6Brass dragon control

8-9Copper dragon control
10Gold dragon control
11-13Green dragon control
14Red dragon control
15Silver dragon control
16-17White dragon control

column20:
'(any)
This potion grants a spell-like ability equivalent to the magic user spell ESP for the duration of 5d8 rounds.'

'(any)
Imbibing the full dose of this potion replenishes damage up to 3d8 + 3 hit points. Unlike most other potions
column21: this can be imbibed in three equal portions for 1d8 hp of healing each.'

column20:
'(any)
The imbiber of this potion is impervious to all forms of ordinary flame
column21: whether as small as a torch or as large as a raging bonfire
column22: for 1 turn. Further
column23: this potion reduces damage from other kinds of fire by –2 per die of damage. These kinds of fire include fireball
column24: wall of fire
column25: and the intense heat of molten rock. If exposure to these flames requires a saving throw
column26: it is made at +4 to the die roll. Half of the potion can be quaffed for resistance lasting 5 rounds
column27: and other bonuses provided are halved (-1 damage and +2 to saving throws).'

column20:
'(any)
This potion grants the spell-like ability equivalent to the magic user spell of the same name.

Fly Description
"This spell grants the power of flight with aerial agility level V to any creature the magic user touches. The base movement rate for flight is 120 ft per round
column21: with the base speed being doubled when diving
column22: halved when climbing. The GM secretly rolls a 1d6 to determine how much time the spell will last after the base duration expires."'

column20:
'(any)
The person who quaffs this potion
column21: in addition to all items on his or her person
column22: takes on a translucent
column23: gaseous consistency and floats at 30 ft per round. This speed can be different depending on natural wind speed in the environment or due to the effects of wind-altering spells. While in gaseous form
column24: the person affected can flow below doors and other small spaces not sealed airtight. Although magical lightening and fire do the gaseous form full damage
column25: while in gaseous form the imbiber is otherwise impervious to other attacks. However
column26: double the normal damage is inflicted by a whirlwind. This potion must be fully imbibed to have effect.'

and the imbiber of this potion temporarily gains the strength score of the appropriate type of giant. This bonus in strength is accompanied by the giant ability to toss rocks at opponents. column20:
'(any)
The imbiber of this potion increases in size up to a maximum of an additional 24 ft. This potion can be quaffed in one-quarter increments such that one one-quarter portion increases size by 6 ft. Note that although the enlarged person gains enough strength to conduct normal movement
column21: gained strength does not apply in any way to combat. However
column22: movement does increase to an equal amount of a giant of equivalent size.'

column20:
'(any)

column20:
'(any)
When this potion is quaffed
column21: the drinker is bestowed with the spell-like ability of invisibility. This potion can be consumed in 1/8 increments
column22: in which case the invisibility granted lasts 1d4 + 2 turns per dose. Any combat action removes the invisibility granted
column23: such that a new dose must be consumed.'

column20:
'(F)
An invulnerability potion makes the drinker impenetrable to normal attacks
column21: attacks by non-magical beings
column22: and attacks by creatures under 4 hit dice. Further
column23: the drinker gains +2 to all saving throws and grants a reduction in armour class by two ranks. This potion may only be consumed by fighters and its effects last 3d6+2 rounds.'

column20:
'(any)
When this potion is quaffed
column21: the drinker is bestowed with the spell-like ability of levitation. The effects of this potion extend to the drinker only
column22: but allow up to 6
column23: 000 gp of weight to be transported as well.'

column20:
'(any)
This potion makes the drinker 1d12 years younger. This restored youth is possible not only for natural ageing
column21: but also for ageing from magic or creature effects. There is some small danger however
column22: since each time a potion of longevity is consumed there is a cumulative 1% probability that all previous age reversals from potions of this type will be negated
column23: raising the character’s age to the age he or she would be without the effects of the potions. It is not possible to drink this potion in increments.'

column20:
'(any)
This potion is not imbibed
column21: but the thin oil is applied to a character and all of his or her belongings in order to achieve an æthereal state for 1d4+4 turns. It takes 3 rounds for the potion to take effect
column22: and it can be negated earlier than the duration by applying a mildly acidic liquid. When æthereal
column23: a character is invisible and can pass through any objects that are not also æthereal.'

column20:
'(any)
This oil is applied to the character in the same way as oil of ætherealness. Any character so coated cannot be restrained or grabbed
column21: and neither wrapped in the grip of constrictor snakes or any other grasping attacks
column22: including binding ropes
column23: chains
column24: or cuffs
column25: magical or otherwise. Simply put
column26: nothing can get a grip on a character coated in this oil. Further
column27: objects can be coated with the oil
column28: and if a floor is coated any individual even standing on the floor will have a 95% probability each round of falling due to slipping. The effects of the oil last 8 hours
column29: but the oil can be cleaned off early with liquid containing alcohol
column31: wine

column20:
'(any)
The imbiber of this potion may become charmed by the next person or creature upon whom he or she lays eyes. The drinker will actually become charmed and besotted by the person or creature if it is of the opposite sex and of similar racial stock. The charm aspect of this potion lasts for 4 + 1d4 turns
column21: but only dispel magic will make the drinker cease to be enthralled by a member of the opposite sex.'

column20:
'(any)
When this potion is quaffed
column21: the drinker gains the ability to make a suggestion
column22: as the magic user spell
column23: to all creatures within 30 ft. Further
column24: this potion makes the imbiber more alluring and grants a 25% bonus to reaction rolls.'

column20:
'(any)
The imbiber of a potion of plant control is able to control plants or plant-like creatures (including fungi and moulds) within an area of 20 ft squared
column21: toa distance of 90 ft. This ability lasts for 5d4 rounds. Plants and plant-like creatures will obey commands to the best of their capacity. For instance
column22: vines can be controlled to wrap around targets
column23: and intelligent plants can be given orders. However
column24: intelligent plant beings (5 or greater intelligence) receive a saving throw vs magic. Similar to other charm-like abilities
column25: one cannot directly control an intelligent plant creature to inflict harm upon itself.'

column20:
'(any)
This potion grants the spell-like ability to polymorph self
column21:
as the fourth level magic user spell.

Polymorph Self description: "This spell enables the magic user to cloak him- or herself in the physical shape of another creature
column22: and to continue shape-shifting at will for the length of the spell’s duration. The transformation is of an entirely lesser order than that of polymorph other
column23: incurring no risk of a system shock or of truly becoming the transformed creature. Changing from one shape to another requires only 30 seconds
column24:
and when the caster returns to his or her original form (ending the spell) he or she will be healed of 1d12 points of any damage inflicted against the polymorphed forms he or she assumed.

The caster can polymorph into forms no smaller than a songbird and no heavier than 2
column25: 000 lbs. Only the movement capabilities of the new form can be used
column26: not its attacks
column27: defences
column28: or other abilities. The magic user can transform him- or herself into a lion
column29: and run as fast as a lion
column30: but his or her claws will do no more damage than a human’s soft fists. Similarly
column31: if he or she transforms into a dragon
column32: he or she will have the dragon’s ability to fly but no breath weapon. As an orc
column33: he or she would be able to use whatever weapons he or she could use in his original shape
column34: but would lack infravision. The caster retains his or her own hit points and armour class."'

column20:
'(any)
This potion doubles combat and movement ability for 5d4 rounds. Thus
column21: if the imbiber can normally move at 90 ft
column22: for the duration of this potion’s effect the imbiber can move at 180 ft. The number of attacks available double as well
column23: but this potion does not decrease spell-casting time. This heightened ability does not come without cost
column24: for the strain it puts on the imbiber’s body ages him or her by 1 year permanently.'

column20: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column21:
th{padding: 3px}(FPR)
Unlike the potion of heroism
column22: the effects of this potion last 5d6 rounds. Extra levels and their accompanied benefits to combat are temporarily granted to the imbiber
column23:
determined by his or her experience level as shown in the table below. Characters above 12th level receive no benefit.
Imbiber LevelLevels GrantedAdditional Hit Dice (d10)
065
1st to 3rd54+1
4th to 6th43+2
7th to 9th32+3
10th to 12th21+4
'

column20:
'(any)
This sweet-tasting liquid can be used to cleanse water (including turning salt water into fresh water) or otherwise transform poisons
column21: acid
column22: etc. into drinkable liquid. Further
column23: sweet water will destroy other potions. For most liquids
column24: this potion will affect up to 100
column25: 000 ft cubed. However
column26: only 1
column27: 000 ft cubed of acid can be neutralised. The effects of sweet water are permanent
column28: and once treated
column29: liquid will resist spoilage or contamination for 5d4 rounds after which it can be contaminated once again.'

column20:
'(any)
For 5d4 rounds
column21: the imbiber of this potion can sense any treasure within 240 ft containing valuable metals or gems. In order to be detected
column22: the total value of the treasure must meet or exceed any combination of 50 gp or 100 gems. Any valuable metal meeting this value in quantity is detectable
column23: and any gems
column24: including those in jewellery
column25: are detectable. Although the direction of the treasure can be sensed
column26: the precise distance cannot. No physical barrier will impede detection
column27: except some magical wards or lead.'

th{padding: 3px}(any)
Normally undead are immune to charm. However
column22: when quaffed this potion grants the drinker the ability to charm undead (intelligent or otherwise) as the charm person spell. Only intelligent undead are allowed a saving throw vs magic
column23: with a penalty of 2. A total of 16 hit dice of undead can be influenced. All hit dice bonuses are rounded down (5 + 2 hit dice is considered as 5). The effects of this potion last 5d4 rounds. Each potion of undead control affects one type of undead

column20:
'(any)
The imbiber of this potion is granted the ability to breathe when submerged in any liquid that contains oxygen (rivers
column21: lakes
column22: oceans
column23: etc.). The duration is 1 hour + 1d10 rounds per dose. There is a 75% probability that a potion will contain 4 doses
column24: and a 25% probability it will contain 2 doses.'

column20: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column21:
th{padding: 3px}(CP)
All demons are unable to enter the protected area for 5d4 rounds. This scroll takes a variable amount of time to read
column22:
to be determined by the power level of the demon.
Demon TypeTime to Read
Class C or weaker3 segments
Class E or weaker7 segments
Greatest demons1 round
'

column20: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column21:
th{padding: 3px}(CP)
This scroll is effective for warding against all devils for 5d4 rounds. If the scroll is read for 1 round
column22: it will repel all devil types. Otherwise
column23:
the scroll may be read for a variable amount of time to offer protection only against some devils.
Devil TypeTime to Read
Lesser devils or lower3 segments
Greater devils or lower7 segments
Arch devils or lower1 round
'

column20: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column21:
th{padding: 3px}(CDIM)
This scroll takes 6 segments to read and wards against elementals for 5d8 rounds. If the scroll wards against only one type of elemental
column22: it is effective against 24 HD of elementals. If the scroll is effective against all forms of elementals
column23: it repels 16 HD. If more elementals are present than can be warded off
column24: these additional beings may enter the area of protection and attack anyone within. Roll on the table below to determine which elementals are warded off by a specific scroll. Note that some creatures that are closely connected with elements
column25: or are a particular form of elemental monster
column26:
may also be warded off at the GM’s discretion.
d20Elemental Type
1-3Air
4-6Earth
7-9Fire
10-12Water
13-20All
'

column24: these additional beings may enter the area of protection and attack anyone within. Roll on the table below to determine which elementals are warded off by a specific scroll. Note that some creatures that are closely connected with elements
column25: or are a particular form of elemental monster
column26:
may also be warded off at the GM’s discretion.
d20Elemental Type
1-3Air
4-6Earth
7-9Fire
10-12Water
13-20All
'

column20: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column21:
th{padding: 3px}(any)
This warding scroll takes 4 segments to read and its effects last for 5d6 rounds. A total of 49 HD of creatures are warded off
column22: and for this calculation any “+” is rounded up if 3 or more
column23: or down if 2 or fewer. Any creatures above these HD may enter the protected area and attack characters within. Roll on the table below to determine which specific creature type a scroll of warding is effective against. Note that if all shape-changers is indicated
column24: this includes any creature that is capable of taking a human form
column25:
as well as creatures under the effects of a polymorph spell or creatures with an innate ability to shape change or polymorph (including druids of high level).
d20Creature Type
1Werebears
2Wereboars
3-4Wererats
5Weretigers
6-8Werewolves
9-19All lycanthropes
20All shape-changers
'

column20:
'(any)
This scroll of warding takes 8 segments to read and has a duration of 5d6 rounds. Unlike other scrolls of warding
column21: the protection offered by this scroll is confined to a 5 ft radius of the scroll reader. This area of protection prevents any magical effects from passing through. Should a magic item pass through the area
column22: there is a 50% probability that the item loses all magical properties (exception: major artifacts will not be so affected). When more than one magic item makes contact with this anti-magic barrier at the same time
column23: the barrier is severely taxed. The GM will roll to check whether an item is drained of its magical properties
column24: in the same approximate order that each item makes contact with the barrier (or in random order). In this circumstance
column25: should a check indicate an item is drained of magic
column26: the barrier is immediately overloaded and dissolves.'

column20:
'(any)
This scroll of warding is read in 5 segments and lasts for 5d4 rounds. All characters within the area of protection are immune to all sources of petrifaction
column21: whether from spells
column22: gaze
column23: breath weapons
column24: or any other source.'

column20:
'(CP)
This scroll is read in 1 round. Most of these scrolls (1-9 on 1d10) have a duration of 10d6 rounds. The remaining scrolls have a duration of 10d6 turns
column21: but the protection is rooted to one 10 ft radius location when cast from the scroll. This scroll wards off all effects that can control the mind
column22: including spells such as magic jar. This scroll prevents any form of mental energy drain
column23: whether magical or some other form. The protection offered by this scroll of warding is extended to all beings
column24: living or dead
column25: within the radius.'

column20:
'(CP)
This scroll of warding takes 4 segments to read
column21: and has a duration of 10d8 rounds. The area of effect is a 5 ft radius from the scroll reader. It wards off 35 HD (or levels) of undead
column22: but any excess creatures are able to pass into the protected area and attack creatures within. Otherwise undead cannot pass through the protective barrier
column23: but can employ ranged attacks or spells into the area from outside. Most scrolls that ward off undead are effective against all forms of undead
column24: but the GM may decide to make some scrolls specific to a form of undead. Refer to the potion of undead control for a table to determine an undead type if this option is used.'
