column20:
'(any)
This scroll is cursed'

'(any)
This rod acts as a magnet
column21:
drawing spells into itself. The magic absorbed must be a single-target spell or a ray directed at either the character possessing the rod or his or her gear. The rod then nullifies the spell effects and stores their potential until the wielder releases this energy in the form of spells of his or her own. He or she can instantly detect the level of the spell as the rod absorbs its energy. Absorption requires no action on the part of the user if the rod is in hand at the time.

The player must keep a running total of absorbed (and used) spell levels. The wielder of the rod can use captured spell energy to cast any spell he or she has prepared in 1 segment without expending the preparation itself (i.e. he or she still has the spell in memory). The only restrictions are that the levels of spell energy stored in the rod must be equal to or greater than the level of the spell the wielder wants to cast
column22: that any material components required for the spell be present
column23:
and that the rod be in hand when casting.

A rod of absorption absorbs a maximum of 50 spell levels and can thereafter only discharge any remaining potential it might have. The rod cannot be recharged. The wielder knows the remaining absorbing potential of the rod and current amount of stored energy. '

column20: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column21:
th{padding: 3px}(any)
This dreaded rod is a bane to magic items
column22: for its touch drains an item of all magical properties. The item touched must make a saving throw to prevent the rod from draining it. Contact is made by making an attack roll. Upon draining an item
column23:
the rod itself becomes brittle and cannot be used again. Drained items are not restorable even by wish. See the table below for magic item saving throws against this draining effect:
Item TypeSave
Potion20
Ring17
Rod14
Scroll19
Staff13
Wand15
Artifact13
Armour and Shields11 (8 if +5)
Sword9 (7 if a holy sword)
Miscellaneous Magic12
Miscellaneous Weapons*10
*Note that a single use of the rod of cancellation may drain many small magical items
column24: if they are contained together. For example
column25: a quiver of magical crossbow bolts.'

column20:
'(CDIM)
With the expenditure of 1 charge
column21: all monsters and characters within a 20 ft radius are charmed by the wielder for 1 turn so long as they are at least minimally intelligent. All charmed beings will hold nothing but respect and awe for the wielder
column22: and will seek to please him or her by doing nearly anything short of harming themselves or violating their alignment.'

column20:
'(FPR)
This rod has functions that are spell-like
column21: and it can also be used as a magic weapon of various sorts. It also has several more mundane uses. The rod of lordly might is metal
column22: thicker than other rods
column23: with a flanged ball at one end and six stud-like buttons along its length. It weighs 10 lbs
column24:
and a strength of 16 or greater is necessary to wield this weapon. Any character with less than 16 strength suffers an attack penalty of –1 per point below 16.

The rod has the following spell-like functions
column25:
each of which costs 1 charge:
  • Fear upon all enemies viewing it
column26:
if the wielder so desires (60 ft maximum range). The target is allowed a save vs magic.
  • Paralyse upon touch
column27: if the wielder so commands. The wielder must choose to use this power and then succeed on a melee touch attack to activate the power. If the attack fails
column28:
the effect is lost. The target is allowed a save vs magic.
  • Deal 2d4 hp of damage to an opponent on a successful touch attack (no save) and cure the wielder of a like amount of damage.

    • The following weapon functions of the rod do not require the use of charges:
    • In its normal form
column29:
the rod can be used as a +2 mace.
  • When button #1 is pushed
column30: the rod becomes a +1 flaming sword. A blade springs from the ball
column31:
with the ball itself becoming the sword’s hilt. The weapon lengthens to an overall length of 3 ft.
  • When button #2 is pushed
column32: the rod becomes a +4 battle axe. A blade springs forth at the ball
column33:
and the whole lengthens to 4 ft.
  • When button #3 is pushed
column34: the rod becomes a +3 spear. The spear blade springs forth
column35: and the handle can be lengthened up to 12 ft (wielder’s choice)
column36: for an overall length of from 6 ft to 15 ft. At its 15 ft length
column37:
the rod is suitable for use as a lance.
The following other functions of the rod do not employ charges:
  • Climbing pole/ladder. When button #4 is pushed
column38: a spike that can anchor in granite is extruded from the ball
column39: while the other end sprouts three sharp hooks. The rod lengthens to anywhere between 5 and 50 ft in a single round
column40: stopping when button 4 is pushed again. Horizontal bars 3 in long fold out from the sides
column42: in staggered progression. The rod is firmly held by the spike and hooks and can bear up to 4
column43:
000 lbs. The wielder can retract the pole by pushing button #5.
  • The ladder function can be used to force open doors. The wielder plants the rod’s base 30 ft or less from the portal to be forced and in line with it
column44:
then pushes button #4. The force exerted has a strength equal to that of a storm giant.
  • When button #6 is pushed
column45:
the rod indicates magnetic north and gives the wielder a knowledge of his or her approximate depth beneath the surface or height above it.
This rod may never be recharged. When the charges are expired
column46: functions that require charges may not be used again
column47: and neither may the rod be employed as a +1 flaming sword nor a +4 battle axe. These attributes are lost.'

column20: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column21:
th{padding: 3px}(C)
This rod may be used to the same effect as the cleric spell resurrection
column22: except the wielder does not age or need to rest after using the rod. The rod may resurrect both humans and demi-humans
column23: including half-orcs and elves. This rod may be used only once each day. A quantity of charges will be expended to resurrect a character based on the character’s race and class. Refer to the table below
column24:
adding the charge cost for each of these variables together. Any character with more than one class will cost the higher quantity of charges for his or her classes.
RaceChargesClassCharges
Human1Fighter2
Half-elf2Paladin1
Half-orc4Ranger2
Halfling2Magic User3
Elf4Illusionist3
Dwarf3Thief3
Gnome3Assassin4
Cleric1
Druid2
The rod of resurrection is not rechargeable.'

column20:
'(FPR)
This rod looks like a royal sceptre. The wielder can command the obedience and fealty of creatures within 120 ft when he or she activates the device. Creatures totalling (1d4×100)+100 hit dice can be ruled
column21: but creatures with intelligence scores of 15 or higher and levels or HD equal to or greater than 12 are entitled to a save vs magic to negate the effect. Ruled creatures obey the wielder as if he or she were their absolute sovereign. Still
column22: if the wielder gives a command that is contrary to the nature of the creatures commanded
column23: the magic is broken. The rod can be used after 5 segments from activation
column24: and each charge expended allows the rod to be used for 1 turn. The rod crumbles to dust once all charges are expended. It may not be recharged.'

column20:
'(CDIM)
A rod of striking deals 1d8+3 hp damage
column21: and functions as a +3 weapon of magical nature. When this rod is used against golems
column22: it always costs 1 charge per successful hit in combat
column23: and deals 2d8+6 hp damage. Note that when employed in this way against a golem
column24: a successful roll of 20 will instantly annihilate the target. In addition
column25: this rod may deal increased damage to night hags
column26: devils
column27: demons
column28: and other infernal beings from the outer planes. When attacking these monsters
column29: a successful attack roll of 20 causes the expenditure of a charge and the rod deals triple normal damage.'

column20:
'(CM)
A staff of compulsion has three primary uses
column21: which are variable in effect and availability depending on whether the staff is wielded by a cleric or a magic user. First
column22: the staff can replicate the effects of a potion of plant control when wielded by a cleric. Plants may be controlled for up to 1 turn in a 10 ft square area per 1 charge expenditure. Second
column23: the staff may replicate the effects of a ring of humanoid control. This costs 1 charge per use. Finally
column24: the third use of the staff replicates the effect of a potion of animal control when wielded by a cleric
column25: and replicates a ring of mammal command when wielded by a magic user. Both of these effects cost 1 charge for use of a period of up to 1 turn increments. For example
column26: 2 turns would cost 2 charges
column27: or 1 turn plus 2 rounds would also cost 2 charges.'

column20:
'(CD)
This staff can cure the following conditions
column21: two times each per day: blindness
column22: disease
column23: injury (3d8+3 hp)
column24: and insanity. This staff may only be employed on an individual humanoid one time per function
column25: per day. For example
column26: the wielder could cure a victim of all conditions the staff can address
column27: but only once for each condition in one day. This staff may be recharged.'

column20:
'(IM)
The staff of power is a very potent magic item
column21: with offensive and defensive abilities. Each of the following spell-like powers cost 1 charge: magic missile
column22: ray of enfeeblement
column23: continual light
column24: darkness 15 ft radius
column25: levitate
column26: lightning bolt
column27: fireball
column28:
and cone of cold.

The staff of power has the following additional spell-like powers
column31:
and shield (5 ft radius).

The wielder of a staff of power gains a +2 bonus to AC and saving throws. The staff is also a +2 quarterstaff
column32: and its wielder may use it to smite opponents. If 1 charge is expended
column33:
the staff causes double damage for 1 round. This effect may not be stacked.

A staff of power can be used for a retributive strike
column34: as the staff of wizardry. A staff of power may be recharged.'

column20:
'(CD)
Two forms of this staff are known to exist
column21:
a python form (60%) and a viper form (40%). Neither form uses charges.

The python strikes as a +2 quarterstaff. If the user throws the staff to the ground
column22: it grows to become a giant (25 ft long) constrictor snake by the end of the round (90 ft move
column23: AC 3
column24: 49 hp). The python obeys all commands of the owner
column25:
and constricts any opponent it successfully attacks for 1d6+3 hp damage per round. The serpent returns to staff form (a full-round action) whenever the wielder desires. If the snake form is killed the staff is irreparably lost.

The viper strikes as a +1 weapon for 1d4+1 hp damage. Once per day
column26: upon command
column27: the head of the staff becomes that of an actual serpent for 1 turn (20 hp
column28: AC 9). During this period
column29: any successful strike with the rod deals its usual damage and also poisons the creature hit. A victim must succeed in a saving throw vs poison or die. The viper only functions if its possessor is evil.'

column20:
'(CD)
Two forms of this staff are known to exist
column21:
a python form (60%) and a viper form (40%). Neither form uses charges.

The python strikes as a +2 quarterstaff. If the user throws the staff to the ground
column22: it grows to become a giant (25 ft long) constrictor snake by the end of the round (90 ft move
column23: AC 3
column24: 49 hp). The python obeys all commands of the owner
column25:
and constricts any opponent it successfully attacks for 1d6+3 hp damage per round. The serpent returns to staff form (a full-round action) whenever the wielder desires. If the snake form is killed the staff is irreparably lost.

The viper strikes as a +1 weapon for 1d4+1 hp damage. Once per day
column26: upon command
column27: the head of the staff becomes that of an actual serpent for 1 turn (20 hp
column28: AC 9). During this period
column29: any successful strike with the rod deals its usual damage and also poisons the creature hit. A victim must succeed in a saving throw vs poison or die. The viper only functions if its possessor is evil.'

column20:
'(CDIM)
A staff of withering acts as a +1 weapon that deals 1d4+1 hit points of damage. In addition
column21: if the wielder chooses to spend 2 charges on a hit
column22: the victim will age 10 years. Spending 3 charges requires the victim to instead save vs magic
column23: or a limb withers into a desiccated
column24: worthless member. The specific limb struck is determined randomly. Note that effects from the staff are stacked
column25: such that a victim hit with the staff when 3 charges are spent will have a limb wither and he or she will age as well.'

column20:
'(M)
The staff of wizardry is a powerful device
column21: granting several spells at the wielder’s disposal. The staff may be used to effect the following spell-like abilities: detect magic
column22: enlarge
column23: hold portal
column24: light
column25:
and protection from good (evil). These abilities do not require the expenditure of charges.

In addition
column26: the staff has the following abilities that cost 1 charge per use: dispel magic
column27: fireball
column28: ice storm
column31: lightning bolt
column34: wall of fire
column35: and web. The following powerful abilities cost 2 charges per use: conjure elemental
column36: plane shift
column37: telekinesis
column38:
and whirlwind (as a genie).

The wielder of the staff receives a bonus of +2 for saving throws vs magic. This staff may be recharged
column39: but only by absorbing magical energies that are cast at the wielder. When a spell is cast at the wielder
column40: he may choose to absorb these energies
column41: at a rate of 1 charge per spell level of the spell directed at him. Note that taking this manoeuvre is the sole action of the staff for that round
column42: and it may not be used for other effects in the same round it absorbs energy. Each staff has a maximum number of possible charges
column43: and it will only safely absorb charges to this limit. The wielder will not know the limit
column44: or how many charges have been used
column45: unless some magical means is employed to discover this. The staff does not reveal this information. Should the staff collect energy in excess of its limit
column46: it detonates in the same manner as in a retributive strike
column47:
as described below.

A staff of wizardry can be used for a retributive strike
column48: requiring it to be broken by its wielder. The breaking of the staff must be intentional and declared by the wielder. All charges currently in the staff are instantly released in a 30 ft radius. All within 10 ft of the broken staff take points of damage equal to 8 × the number of charges in the staff
column49: those 10 ft to 20 ft away take 6 × the number of charges in damage
column50: and those 20 ft to 30 ft distant take 4 × the number of charges in damage. All those affected can make saving throws vs magic to reduce the damage by half. The character breaking the staff has a 50% chance of travelling to another plane of existence
column51: but if he or she does not
column52:
the explosive release of spell energy destroys him or her. Only the staff of wizardry and the staff of power may be used for a retributive strike.

After all charges are used up from the staff
column53: it remains a +2 quarterstaff. Once empty of charges
column54: it cannot be used for a retributive strike.'

column20:
'(CDIM)
When activated
column21: this wand will vibrate and point to the most powerful magic within 30 ft of the wand wielder. If used continuously for more than 1 round
column22: in further rounds the wand will reveal additional sources of magic
column23: in approximate descending rank of their relative power. Should the wielder use a round focusing the wand on a source of magic
column24: the wand will reveal the form of magic it is (such as illusion or charm). This wand may be used for 1 continuous turn per charge spent. However
column25: for each continuous round of use (after the first round) there is a 1% cumulative probability that the wand will offer information that is opposite to the reality. In this case magic items will appear mundane
column26: or non-magical items will seem to radiate magic.'

column20:
'(any)
Like other wands of detection
column21: this wand will vibrate and point to the item it is enchanted to detect
column22: in this case
column23: the largest quantity of a mineral or metal within a 30 ft range. The wand may also be used to detect all samples of a specific mineral or metal within range
column24: such as gold or diamonds. The wielder of the wand becomes aware of the quantity of the item when detected. This wand requires 1 round per use
column25: and may be used continuously for 1 turn per charge spent. The wand of detecting minerals and metals can be recharged.'

column20:
'(any)
The wielder of this wand may choose
column21: each round
column22: to detect traps (range of 30 ft) or a secret door (range of 15 ft). The wand will vibrate and point to the desired object. Each round of use requires 1 charge
column23: and it is rechargeable.'

column20:
'(any)
A wand of enemy detection can
column21: at the expenditure of 1 charge
column22: detect any being with harmful or unkind intentions toward the wand wielder
column23: within 60 ft. The wand will throb in the user’s hand and point in the direction of such a being. The being need not be in obvious sight
column24: and the wand can detect it even if it is hiding
column25: invisible
column26: or otherwise outside of normal space
column27: such as when in astral or æthereal form. A wand of enemy detection may be recharged.'

column20:
'(CDIM)
Once per round
column21: by spending 1 charge
column22: this wand will emit a ray of sinister purple light that takes 1 segment to appear. The ray is shaped as a cone 20 ft wide at its terminal end and 60 ft long. Any being within the area of effect must succeed in a saving throw vs wands or fall under effects identical to the cleric spell fear. A wand of fear is rechargeable.'

column20:
'(DM)
A wand of fire produces several spell-like effects
column21: and may only produce one effect per round. The following effects require the expenditure of 1 charge: burning hands shoots forth a triangular cone of fire 12 ft long with a 10 ft ending width. It takes 1 segment for this effect to manifest
column22: and it lasts but a moment. Any being within this area of effect suffers 6 hp damage. Pyrotechnics may also be produced from the wand
column23:
and take 2 segments to appear. This effect exactly mimics the spell of the same name.

The wand of fire may produce the following effects with the expenditure of 2 charges: a fireball may be shot from the wand
column24: performing exactly as the spell of the same name
column25: as if cast from a 6th level character. It deals 6d6 hp damage to all within the area of effect (save vs wands for half damage). Any result of 1 on a damage die is treated as a 2. A wall of fire may be produced in 3 segments
column26:
like the spell of the same name cast from a 6th level character. The wall may be formed into a 22 ft diameter circle surrounding the wand wielder.

This wand is rechargeable.'

column20:
'(DM)
A wand of ice produces several spell-like effects
column21: and may only produce one effect per round. The following effects require the expenditure of 1 charge: an ice storm (as the magic user spell) wreaks its cold havoc to a distance of 60 ft
column22: and appears in 1 segment; a wall of ice can be brought into existence
column23: taking 2 segments to appear. It always has a thickness of 6 in
column24: but may have any surface area as commanded by the wand wielder to a maximum of 600 sq ft (for example
column25:
25 × 24 ft or 10 × 60 ft).

The wand of ice may produce a cone of cold with the expenditure of 2 charges. The cone is 20 ft in diameter at its maximum length of 60 ft. This effect manifests in 2 segments
column26: and is present for only a moment. Nonetheless
column27:
it deals 6d6 hp damage to all within the area of effect (save vs wands for half damage). Any result of 1 on a damage die is treated as a 2.

The wand of ice is rechargeable.'

column20:
'(CDIM)
A wand of light produces several spell-like effects
column21: and may only produce one effect per round. The following effects require the expenditure of 1 charge: dancing lights as the magic user spell
column22: which appears in 1 segment
column23: and light as the magic user spell
column24:
which appears in 2 segments.

The wielder may spend 2 charges to create continual light
column25: which takes 2 segments to manifest. Finally
column26: by spending 3 charges
column27: the wielder may create a ray of intense sunlight. This effect manifests in 3 segments. The bright golden-yellow light lasts only a moment
column28: has a range of 120 ft
column29: and forms a 40 ft diameter sphere of light. Any being within the area must save vs wands or be blinded and stunned for 2d6 segments. The golden sphere of light has a devastating effect on all undead
column31: with no saving throw allowed.'

column20:
'(IM)
his wand is capable of producing both visual and audible illusions
column21: each requiring a charge per round the illusion is maintained. The illusory effect worked by the wielder manifests in 3 segments
column22: and requires full concentration to maintain. The wielder may not engage in any combat or complex action
column23: but may move at normal speed. This wand is rechargeable.'

column20:
'(DM)
If the wielder of a wand of lighting hits an opponent (in melee) with the wand and spends 1 charge
column21: he or she may deliver an electrical charge to his or her victim
column22: which inflicts 1d10 hp damage. No saving throw is permitted
column23: and for AC purposes a victim wearing metal armour has an AC of 10
column24: regardless of magical armour bonuses. Non-metal armour and items such as a ring of protection do apply
column25:
however.

By spending 2 charges
column26: the wielder of this wand may produce a lightning bolt
column27: similar to the magic user spell
column28:
to inflict 6d6 hp of damage. Any result of 1 on a damage die is treated as a 2. A save vs wands is allowed for half damage.

A wand of lightning can be recharged.'

column20:
'(M)
This wand may fire 1 or 2 magic missiles (wielder’s choice)
column21: as the spell
column22: each round. Each missile requires 1 charge and 3 segments before it manifests. These magical bolts deal 1d4+1 hp damage each.'

column20:
'(CDIM)
This device negates the spell or spell-like function or functions of magic items. The wielder points the rod at the magic item
column21: and a pale grey beam shoots forth to touch the target device or being after 1 segment. The ray negates any function of all wands
column22: and any other target item or magical effect (including spells cast by the target) has a 25% chance of resisting the negation. Each use of the wand costs 1 charge
column23: and may be used one time per round. A wand of negation can never be recharged.'

column20:
'(CDIM)
A wand of paralysation may fire a ghoulish green beam of energy once per round
column21: to a range of 60 ft. The beam will paralyse any one victim who fails a save vs wands. The effect has a duration of 5d4 rounds. The beam of energy manifests after 3 segments. This wand is rechargeable.'

column20:
'(DM)
By pointing the wand and giving a command
column21: the wielder may fire a crackling beam of pure black energy at a target. If the victim fails a saving throw vs wands
column22: he or she is affected as if by the magic user spell polymorph other
column23: to transform into any creature the wielder desires. Instead
column24: the wielder may strike a being with the wand
column25: which surrounds the subject in flickering black shadows and causes him or her to be affected as if by the magic user spell polymorph self. In this case
column26: the wielder pronounces the name of the creature into which the victim will transform as he or she touches the opponent. A saving throw is permitted
column27: but a willing subject may choose to forgo the save.'

column20:
'(CDIM)
The wielder of this wand
column21: when holding the wand by hand (not when it is packed away) is able to instantly identify spells of a conjuration or summoning nature
column22: either when seen written or actively cast. The wielder may spend a charge to cast the spells unseen servant or monster summoning. To cast monster summoning
column23: the wielder must be of sufficient level to cast the version employed (I
column24: II
column25: III
column26: IV
column27: V or VI)
column28: and it requires 5 segments. When casting monster summoning
column29: the wielder may spend up to 6 charges
column30: to stack the effects as if more than one spell were cast. For example
column31: the 6 charges could be spent to cast monster summoning VI
column32: or they could be used to cast monster summoning I six times
column34:
or any other combination totalling 6.

A wand of summoning can produce the effects of a prismatic sphere (it may be formed into a wall). However
column36: the wand may only produce a single colour type at a time
column37: per use each round. Each use costs 1 charge
column38:
and takes 5 segments to appear.

The wand is also capable of bringing into existence a veil of darkness
column39: by spending 2 charges. This effect takes 5 segments to cast. This veil can occupy a space equal to 600 ft squared
column40: and can take any dimensions equalling this amount (20 × 30 ft
column42: etc.) No light may pass through the veil
column43:
but other magical effects and physical objects may pass through it normally.

A wand of summoning is rechargeable.'

column20: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column21:
th{padding: 3px}(any)
A wand of wonder is a strange and unpredictable device that randomly generates any number of weird effects each time it is used. Each use costs 1 charge. In some cases a saving throw is appropriate. The effects should be considered typical of those possible
column22:
but the GM may adjust these or create new effects depending on the situation. Typical powers of the wand include the following:
d%Wondrous Effect
01–05Slow creature pointed at for 1 turn.
06–10Faerie fire surrounds the target.
11–15Deludes wielder for 1 round into believing the rod functions as indicated by a second die roll (no save).
16–20Gust of wind
column23: but at twice the power.21–25Wielder learns target’s surface thoughts (as with ESP) for 1d4 rounds.26–30Stinking cloud at 30 ft range.31–33Heavy rain falls for 1 round in 60 ft radius centred on wand wielder.34–36Summon an animal—a rhino (01–25 on d%)
column24: elephant (26–50)
column25: or mouse (51–100).37–46Lightning bolt (70 ft long
column26: 5 ft wide)
column27: 6d6 damage.47–49Stream of 600 large butterflies pours forth and flutters around for 2 rounds
column28: blinding everyone (including wielder).50–53Enlarge victim if within 60 ft of wand.54-58Darkness
column30: centred 30 ft away from wand.59–62Grass grows in 160 ft square area before the wand
column31: or grass existing there grows to ten times normal size.63–65Vanish any nonliving object of up to 1
column32: 000 lb mass and up to 30 ft cubed in size.66–69Reduce wielder to 1/12 height.70–79Fireball
column34: as wand.80–84Invisibility covers wand wielder.85–87Leaves grow from target if within 60 ft of wand.88–9010–40 gems
column36: shoot forth in a 30 ft long stream. Each gem deals 1 point of damage to any creature in its path: roll 5d4 for the number of hits.91–95Shimmering colours dance and play over a 40 × 30 ft area in front of wand. Creatures therein are blinded for 1d6 rounds.96–97Wielder (50% chance) or target (50% chance) turns permanently blue
column37: green
column38: or purple.98–00Flesh to stone (or stone to flesh if target is stone already) if target is within 60 ft.'

column20:
'(any)
When worn
column21: this ring increases the wearer’s charisma ability score to 18. Note this is not a permanent increase; if the ring is removed the wearer’s charisma returns to its normal value. This magical ring also bestows two spell-like abilities
column22: each usable once per day and requiring 3 segments of casting time. First
column23: during the course of conversation the wearer can make a suggestion
column24: as per the 3rd level magic user spell
column25: to any human or demi-human or humanoid. Second
column26: the wearer of the ring of charisma can also charm up to 21 levels/hit dice or humans or humanoids as per the 1st level magic user spell charm person. This is an exceptionally powerful item and the GM may wish to limit the ring of charisma by giving it a limited number of charges.'

column20:
'(any)
The wearer of this ring is protected by a feather fall spell any time he or she falls more than 5 ft.'

'(any)
This ring grants immunity to normal fires such as torches or flaming oil. Very hot fires such as molten lava or hell hound breath inflict only 1 hp of damage per segment
column21: and even then only if the wearer is directly touching or targeted by such. Exceptionally hot fires such as red dragon breath or fireballs inflict -2 points of damage per die (but always inflict at least 1 point of damage) and saving throws are rolled at +4. The following rule of thumb should assist with determining damage reduction: “very hot” fires inflict up to 24 points of maximum damage
column22: “exceptionally hot” fires cause 25 or more points of maximum damage.'

column20:
'(any)
This magic item permits the wearer to move freely under any conditions. This applies even if the wearer is attacked by a hold person
column21: slow
column22: or web spell; and also negates environmental effects such as the individual being underwater. The individual can move at normal movement rates and do full damage with melee weapons
column23: though missile and hurled weapons will be subject to the spell or environmental effects as appropriate. Though the ring of free action grants freedom of movement underwater
column24: it should be noted the ring does not grant the ability to breathe underwater.'

column20:
'(any)
This powerful magic ring can call a mighty genie from the Elemental Plane of Air to do the wearer’s bidding. The genie takes 1 round to appear and will follow the letter (not necessarily the spirit) of the wearer’s command to the best of its ability. If the genie is killed the ring crumbles into dust. This is an exceptionally powerful item and the GM may wish to limit the ring of genie summoning by giving it a limited number of charges.'

'(any)
When donned
column21: this ring grants the wearer the ability to become instantly invisible at will as per the 2nd level magic user spell. There is a 10% chance the ring has the secondary effect of making the user inaudible as well. Just as attacking while invisible negates invisibility
column22: so does speaking while inaudible break the inaudibility feature.'

column21: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td

column23: for instance) subject to the following limitations: if magic armour is worn the wearer’s AC will not be increased
column24: though the saving throw bonus will still apply. Also
column25: only one ring of protection may be worn at a time. If two are worn
column26: the stronger of the two will function. Various types of rings of protection are listed below
column27:
with dice throws to determine type randomly if the GM desires.

column20:
'(any)
Wearing this ring allows the user to regenerate 1 hp per turn
column21: regrow lost limbs and organs
column22: and even return from the dead with no constitution penalty or roll. If the cause of death was due to poison
column23: however
column24: the poison will need to be neutralised or a saving throw made or the wearer will die again. One should note only damage accumulated while wearing the ring can be healed by the ring’s power. Removing the ring of regeneration will naturally result in the cessation of the healing process. 10% of these rings (91-100 on d%) are a special type
column25: called rings of vampiric regeneration. Vampiric rings do not regenerate any hp per turn
column26:
but will bestow half value of all damage (rounded down) inflicted upon one’s opponents in hand to hand combat to the wearer of the ring.

For example: If the fighter Grabbo the Lusty inflicts 11 points of damage with his longsword upon his hobgoblin opponent while wearing a ring of vampiric regeneration
column27: up to 5 hit points of Grabbo’s damage will be immediately healed. This process works only with melee weapons; the ring cannot use damage caused by missile fire
column28: hurled weapons
column29: or spells. Note that neither type of this ring can increase the wearer’s hp beyond the normal total.'

column20:
'(any)
Wearing this ring allows the user to regenerate 1 hp per turn
column21: regrow lost limbs and organs
column22: and even return from the dead with no constitution penalty or roll. If the cause of death was due to poison
column23: however
column24: the poison will need to be neutralised or a saving throw made or the wearer will die again. One should note only damage accumulated while wearing the ring can be healed by the ring’s power. Removing the ring of regeneration will naturally result in the cessation of the healing process. 10% of these rings (91-100 on d%) are a special type
column25: called rings of vampiric regeneration. Vampiric rings do not regenerate any hp per turn
column26:
but will bestow half value of all damage (rounded down) inflicted upon one’s opponents in hand to hand combat to the wearer of the ring.

For example: If the fighter Grabbo the Lusty inflicts 11 points of damage with his longsword upon his hobgoblin opponent while wearing a ring of vampiric regeneration
column27: up to 5 hit points of Grabbo’s damage will be immediately healed. This process works only with melee weapons; the ring cannot use damage caused by missile fire
column28: hurled weapons
column29: or spells. Note that neither type of this ring can increase the wearer’s hp beyond the normal total.'

column20:
'(any)
A ring that can magically store 2-5 spells and grants the wearer the ability to cast them as if he or she were a spell caster of the required type. Casting a spell from the ring requires 5 segments. Roll d%
column21: a roll of 01-70 means the ring stores magic user spells and 71-00 indicates clerical spells. 10% of magic user rings of spell storing will contain illusionist spells instead
column22: and 25% of clerical rings of spell storing will contain druid spells instead. Roll 2d4 to determine number of spells the ring can contain. To randomly determine the spell levels of each spell
column23: roll 1d6 (on a result of 6 reroll for level with 1d4) for cleric
column24: druid or illusionist spells
column25: and 1d8 (on a result of 8 reroll for level with 1d6) for magic user spells. Once type
column26: number
column27: and level of spells is determined
column28: the GM must decide which spells the ring contains. The spells can either be hand-picked or the GM may use the OSRIC magic tables and dice for spells randomly. Once the class of spells
column30: and the exact spells to be stored are determined
column31:
that capability can never be changed. Charging the ring requires a spell caster to cast the specific spell to be stored with the ring as the target of the spell.

Example of Ring of Spell Storing Creation: Jerry the GM decides to place a ring of spell storing in a red dragon’s treasure hoard. He rolls a 57 on d%
column32: indicating the ring contains magic user spells. A second d% roll yields a 05 and this means the ring really contains spells of the illusionist class. Jerry now rolls 2d4 and gets 1 on both dice
column33: meaning the ring will contain 2 spells total. Jerry now rolls 1d6 twice
column34: one for each spell to determine the level of that spell. The first result is a 2
column35: the second is a 6. The 6 needs to be rerolled on a 1d4 and rolling that die generates a result of 4. So
column36: the GM now knows the ring will hold 2 illusionist spells
column37: one of level 2 and one of level 4. Jerry decides to let fate take a hand in the selection of the exact spells the ring stores and takes a look at the illusionist spell tables in the OSRIC manual. There are 12 level 2 illusionist spells
column38: and 8 level 4 spells
column39: so Jerry grabs a d12 and a d8 and rolls them both. The d12 rolls a 4 so Jerry notes the result of detect magic. The d8 rolls an 8 and Jerry notes the result of shadow monsters. Now that the exact properties of the ring of spell storing have been determined
column40: they can never be changed; the ring will ever after only hold the two illusionist spells noted. If the finder of the ring uses it to cast a detect magic spell
column41: then an illusionist must cast a detect magic upon the ring to recharge that spell slot.'

column20: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column21:
th{padding: 3px}(any)
This magic ring creates a powerful magic aura around the wearer that will partially reflect any spells cast at him or her back onto the spell caster. There are three exceptions to the spell turning ability the ring bestows:
  • Area effect spells which are not directly targeted upon the ring bearer cannot be turned.
  • Touch-based spells cannot be turned.
  • Spell effects delivered by devices are not turned. Examples include: rods
column22: staves
column23: wands
column24:
rings. Note: spell scrolls are not considered devices.
When a spell is cast at the wearer of the ring of spell turning
column25: he or she rolls a d10 and multiplies the result by 10. When damage from the spell attack is determined
column26: the number generated by this roll indicates what percentage of the damage is reflected back upon the attacker. Thus if “6” appears on the d10
column27: 60% of the damage rolled would be deducted from the attacking spell-caster’s hit points and 40% from the target. Further
column28: for each 10% of difference between the damage percentage rolled and 100%
column29: the ring-bearer gains +1 to his or her saving throw. Going back to the example above
column30:
the spell’s target would get a +6 to his or her saving throw and the spell caster would gain a +4.

The ring of spell turning also grants a saving throw against spells which normally do not allow one. In such a case
column31: the save will be half of the percentage die roll for spell reflection. Returning once again to the example above
column32: the ring wearer rolling a 60% chance of reflecting an attacking spell would gain a 30% saving throw
column33:
reducing or negating effects as appropriate to the spell.

Spells that only affect a certain number of levels must be able to affect the target’s and caster’s levels combined
column34: otherwise the spell has no effect on either party. If the ring’s wearer wishes to receive the effects of a targeted spell
column35: he or she must first remove the ring. (Healing spells are exempt
column36: since they are touch-based.) If both caster and target are wearing rings of spell turning
column37:
roll d% and consult the table below.
d%Result
01-70Spell fails completely
column38: no effect on target or caster71-80Spell takes full effect on both target and caster81-97Spell fails and both rings are destroyed98-00A rift into the Positive Material Plane opens
column39: both target and caster are sucked in'

column20:
'(any)
This magic jewellery bestows the ability to swim at a movement rate of 210 ft
column21: if the wearer is clad in appropriate garments. The wearer can also dive up to 50 ft into the water without injury
column22: assuming a water depth of 1 1/2 ft for every 10 ft of diving distance. The wearer may hold his or her breath for 4 rounds
column23: and can swim for up to 4 hours before needing an hour of rest. This rest can be gained while floating
column24: since the ring also grants the ability to stay afloat under all but hurricane conditions.'

column20:

column21: grants a +2 to all saving throws vs cold based attacks
column22: and reduces damage from cold based attacks by -1 per die (minimum damage of 1 point per die).'

column23: oil

column25: or even lava (though heat damage would still apply). The wearer’s feet do not actually contact the surface of the liquid but semi-solid liquids such as snow or mud will show vaguely footprint-like depressions evidencing the wearer’s passing. The ring has a weight limit of 1

column20:
'(CDIM)
An ornate bronze or brass bottle sealed with a lead stopper engraved with many runes of power
column21: though often a thin stream of smoke can be seen leaking from the seal. Once per day the command word can be spoken
column22: allowing the bottle to be opened. Doing so frees an afreeti imprisoned within. Roll d%; 01-10 means the freed afreeti is insane and immediately attacks anyone near the bottle
column23: though it will not fight to the death. Unless the afreeti clearly outmatches the party it will likely melee a few rounds and then flee to its home plane. On a result of 91-00 the afreeti grants the owner 3 wishes then immediately disappears forever. The rest of the time (11-90) the afreeti will agree to serve the owner of the bottle for up to 10 minutes that day and follow all commands to the best of its ability. Every time the afreeti is freed from its prison this result must be rechecked.'

column20:
'(any)
Ahmek was a wizard turned sage who
column21: legends say
column22: was always forgetting to put money in his purse. This magic item is an exquisitely-crafted leather poke sewn from four leather panels
column23: alternating black with a golden yellow colour. When found
column24: the purse will contain the following: 5 cp
column25: 5 sp
column26: 2 ep
column27: 15 gp
column28: 3 pp. No matter how many coins are removed from or added to the poke
column29: the number of coins will always reset to these amounts at midnight.'

column20: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column21:
th{padding: 3px}(IM)
This jug appears as an ordinary ewer or beaker
column22: but will
column23: on command
column24:
produce various liquids when poured. The type and quantity of liquid is as follows:
LiquidAmount
Salt water16 gallons
Fresh water8 gallons
Beer4 gallons
Vinegar2 gallons
Wine1 gallon
Ammonia1 quart
Oil1 pint
Aqua regia8 ounces
Alcohol4 ounces
Chlorine1 ounce
Cyanide1⁄2 ounce


The amount listed for each liquid can be produced up to 7 times per day
column25: at a maximum rate of 2 gallons per round. Only one type of liquid can be produced per day
column26: however.'

column20:
'(any)
This magic necklace grants the wearer a constitution bonus of +1.'

'(any)
The wearer of this broach is protected against attacks on his or her soul. The charm completely safeguards its wearer from possession
column21: whether as the result of a spell or through the efforts of a demon
column22: devil or like being. Furthermore
column23: should the wearer be slain
column24: his or her soul will enter the amulet and be protected for up to 1 week. If the amulet is destroyed during that time
column25: however
column26: the soul is destroyed along with it.'

column20:
'(any)
A magical necklace which
column21: when worn
column22: bestows a bonus of +1 “to hit” on all weapon-less physical attacks.'

'(any)
This amulet enables its wearer
column21: once experienced with its use
column22: to instantaneously and without error travel to extra-planar realities. Until the wearer learns how to use the amulet
column23: however
column24: the destination will be entirely random!'

column2: 'Amulet of Proof Against Detection or Location'
column20:
'(any)
This amulet provides protection against all forms of scrying. Thus spells such as clairvoyance or clairaudience
column21: devices such as crystal balls
column22: and mental or magical powers such as ESP or telepathy (or
column23: in fact
column24: anything short of consulting a major extra-planar power) are completely ineffective in locating its wearer.'

column20:
'(any)
This device appears to be a large iron barrel. A secret compartment at one end contains 10 levers
column21:
each of which controlling a different aspect of the apparatus.
  1. extend/retract legs and tail
  2. uncover/cover forward porthole
  3. uncover/cover side portholes
  4. extend/retract pincers and feelers
  5. snap pincers
  6. move forward/reverse
  7. move left/right
  8. open/close “eyes” that shine with continual light
  9. raise/sink
  10. open/close hatch

The apparatus moves at 30 ft per round forward and 60 ft per round in reverse. The pincers snap for 2d6 damage each
column22: attacking as a 4HD monster but treating all AC as 0 (modified by dexterity adjustments
column23: if any). They can be extend to a maximum of 4 ft from the barrel. The apparatus itself has an AC of 0 and can sustain 100 hit points of damage before leaking and 200 hp of damage before collapsing entirely. It can dive to a maximum depth of 900 ft and can hold 2 medium-sized creatures for 2-5 hours before needing to replenish its air supply.'

column20:
'(any)
This appears to be an ordinary arrow
column21: although a detect magic spell will reveal that it has eldritch properties. Unlike other magic arrows
column22: its enchantment does not aid in combat
column23: however. Instead
column24: once per day the arrow of direction can be used — by tossing it in the air and noting which direction it points when it lands — to show the way to one of several specific features: a stairway or sloping passage (either up or down)
column25: or the entrance or exit to a dungeon
column26: cavern or cave. The feature sought must be identified either by distance (nearest
column27: lowest
column28: etc.) or by direction (north
column30: etc.). The query can be repeated up to 7 times over the next 7 turns.'

column21: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column22:
th{padding: 3px}(any)
A most wonderful item
column23: this is a bag larger on the inside than on the outside. This magical sack also reduces the apparent weight of the contents of the bag. Bag capacity
column24: volume
column25: weight
column26: and apparent weight all vary by type-listed on the table below. Overloading the bag destroys both bag and contents
column27: as does piercing the bag from either without or within. Turning a bag inside out empties all contents out onto the ground and the bag cannot be used again until it is turned back. A living creature can be placed into the bag but there is only enough air to sustain for 10 minutes
column28:
after which the creature will suffocate and die.

The extra-dimensional space of the bag of holding is incompatible with that of the portable hole. Placing a bag of holding into a portable hole will open a rift into the Astral Plane and suck both objects and their content into Astral space
column29: lost forever. If a portable hole is placed into a bag of holding
column30: a gate into the Astral Plane is opened
column31:
destroying both objects and pulling anyone standing within 10 ft into the Astral Plane.
TypeWeight
column34: c. ftI1525030II2550070III351

column23: detailed below
column24: but all work the same way. The owner reaches into the bag and draws out the small
column25: fuzzy ball inside. The ball can be thrown up to 20 ft away and it then becomes an animal which will serve the user for 10 minutes
column26: until slain
column27: or until ordered back into the bag. The animal is under control of the person who drew it from the bag and will follow simple commands such as attack
column28: stay
column31: and the like. Each of the three types
column34:
determined randomly every time the bag is used. Only 1 animal may exist at a time and a maximum of 10 animals may be drawn from the bag in 1 week.

A tiny bead of what appears to be made of dull
column21: black glass. This item can be hurled up to 60 ft with no range penalty incurred
column22: exploding on impact and dealing 5d6 points of damage to all creatures within 10 ft of the point of impact. The explosion also creates a resilient sphere with a radius of 10 ft and a duration of 10 minutes. The bead’s target will be imprisoned within a sphere of energy that can only be dispelled by a rod of cancellation
column23: a rod of negation
column24: disintegrate
column25: or a targeted dispel magic spell. A dispelled resilient sphere will vanish harmlessly. Nothing can pass into or out of the sphere
column26: though there is enough air contained within the sphere to prevent the prisoner from suffocating. The sphere is immovable from its initial location by any magical or physical means.'

column20:
'(any)
A blue crystalline object about the size and shape of a sling bullet
column21: the blemish blotter soaks up imperfections from gemstones. Any gemstone within 6 inches of a blemish blotter for more than 1 minute has a 20% chance of increasing in value by 20%. Improving a jewel costs the blotter 1 charge and every blotter has (1d6 × 10) + 40 charges. As charges are expended
column22: the heart of the blotter turns scarlet and this area grows with each expended charge. When the last charge is expended the scarlet blotter crumbles into dust. This item can affect no jewel more than once.'

column20:
'(IM)
An exceptionally well-made travelling spell book with magical properties
column21: the blessed book is about 12 in × 8 in and 1 in thick
column22: with 1
column23: 000 pages. The book is quite durable; iron bound and inlaid with silver protective runes and a sturdy lock. A magic user or illusionist can write spells into the blessed book without incurring the costs normally associated with inscribing spells in a spell book or travelling spell book. When found as a randomly-generated treasure
column24: this book is usually empty of spells.'

column21:
'(any)
A 12 in × 12 in × 6 in wooden box which can be used as an ordinary storage container. The box is capable of unfolding itself into two different sized water vessels
column22: depending upon the command word used. The first type of vessel is a boat 10 ft × 4 ft × 2 ft and comes complete with: 1 pair of oars
column23: anchor
column24: mast
column25: and lateen sail. The second form
column26: a ship
column27: is 24 ft × 8 ft × 6 ft and comes equipped with 5 pairs of oars
column28: anchor
column31: a deck and hold
column33: and single rowing seats. Any objects stored in the box before transformation are now stowed in the vessel. The boat can comfortably hold four human sized passengers and the ship can easily accommodate 15. Upon command
column34: the boat or ship will fold back into a box.'

column20:
'(any)
Soft leather footwear which allows one to move silently
column21: even in the worst of conditions such as a creaky stair. Chance of success varies from about 95% for the absolute worst conditions to 100% for most conditions.'

column20:
'(any)
Allow the user to levitate or descend up to 20 ft per round
column21: no limit on usage. These boots are not capable of lifting a total weight of more than about 600 lbs. Aerial agility level is only I.'

column20:
'(any)
When activated by clicking one’s heels together
column21: the wearer’s movement speed is doubled and his or her AC improves by +2.'

column20:
'(any)
This magical footwear increases the wearer’s base speed to 120 ft and grants the ability to spring vertically 15 ft
column21: backward 9 ft and forward 30 ft. This springing movement can be used in combat to attack and spring away if the wearer has initiative but under such conditions the wearer has a base 20% chance to stumble
column22: decreased by 1% for every point of dexterity over 12. Carved into the side of the left boot heel is the name “Jak”.'

column20:
'(any)
Allow the user to teleport
column21: as the spell
column22: up to 3 times per day.'

column20:
'(any)
These boots allow movement at normal rates across snow and the wearer will leave no tracks to mark his or her passage. Boots of the winterlands also allow normal movement across ice and icy surfaces without slipping or falling
column21: though the surface must be horizontal. The boots also affect the wearer as an endure cold spell as long as they are worn
column22: with no time limit.'

column21:
'(any)
When the command word is spoken
column22: these ordinary appearing boots sprout wings at the heel and allow the wearer to fly
column23: as the spell (aerial agility: level IV). This power is usable up to 3 times per day with a maximum duration of 5 minutes per flight.'

column20:
'(any)
An ordinary-appearing stoppered glass bottle. When uncorked in an airless environment
column21: however
column22: the bottle will produce a steady stream of air until it is again within a breathable atmosphere or the bottle is recapped. This allows the holder to breathe underwater by “drinking” from the bottle. The bottle may even be passed among multiple users.'

column20:
'(DM)
A stoneware bowl 1 ft in diameter
column21: 6 inches deep
column22: and usually made of a semi-precious stone; malachite
column23: jade
column24: or lapis lazuli are particularly favoured for this purpose. Filling the bowl with water and chanting the summoning words for 1 round causes a 12HD water elemental to appear. The creature summoned behaves as if called by a conjure elemental spell. Only one water elemental may be summoned at a time; a new one cannot be called forth until the previous elemental is dismissed
column25: slain
column26: or dispelled. If salt water is used instead of fresh water
column27: the summoned elemental will have 16 HD rather than 12.'

column20:
'(CDIM)
A finely-made silver charm bracelet with four charms. The wearer may key each charm to a specific person and thereafter when the charm is grasped and the keyed individual’s name spoken
column21: that person is summoned to the wearer’s location
column22: along with all of his or her equipment. The summoned person must be on the same plane as the wearer
column23: and must willingly answer the call (the keyed individual knows who is issuing the summons). Each individual charm has 1 use and disappears afterwards
column24: if separated from the bracelet the charm becomes worthless.'

column21:
'(AFPRT)
This pair of items grants proficiency in the use of any bow or crossbow. If the wearer is already proficient in the use of a bow he or she will gain +2 to attack and +1 damage when using that weapon.'

'(AFPRT)
Similar to the greater bracers of archery
column22: but these only grant +1 to hit and no damage bonus for wearers already proficient with a bow or crossbow.'

When worn
column22: this pair of armoured wrist guards grant from +1 to +8 magical enhancement to the wearer’s AC—but only when the wearer wears no other armour
column23: nor a shield. These bracers are therefore highly prized by magic users. Determine gp value by squaring the AC bonus (i.e.

column20:
'(DM)
When a fire is lit in this black iron brazier
column21: and the words of summoning chanted for 1 round
column22: a 12 HD fire elemental appears and behaves as if called by a conjure elemental spell. If brimstone is added to the fire before chanting
column23: the fire elemental will be of 16 HD. Only one fire elemental may be summoned at a time; a new one cannot be called forth until the previous elemental is dismissed
column24: slain
column25: or dispelled.'

column20:
'(any)
This shoulder pin grants the wearer a +1 to AC and saving throws
column21: and also has the affect of sending a silent boast to all living creatures in the area. This boast is a mental effect much like ESP
column22: touting the wearer’s prowess in battle
column23: and therefore does not work on the undead or mindless creatures. The boast has the result of doubling the chances of wandering monsters
column24: a +10% to any opponent’s morale checks
column25: and a -10% to reaction bonus checks. Once a person touches the brooch
column26: he or she will be unable to rid themselves of it until a remove curse or atonement is cast upon the unfortunate victim.'

column20:
'(any)
In addition to its mundane function as a clasp for a cloak or cape
column21: this brooch can absorb magic missiles generated either by spell or spell-like ability. After absorbing 101 points of magic missile damage
column22: the brooch melts into a useless clump of metal.'

column20:
'(M)
This broom allows the user to fly up to 9 hours cumulative per day. Carrying up to 200 lbs the broom travels at 40 ft and carrying up to 400 lbs the broom travels 30 ft. The broom can be commanded to auto-pilot to any destination named by the owner at a speed of 40 ft
column21: so long as the owner is reasonably familiar with the location and layout of the intended destination. The broom can be summoned to its rider with a command word from as far as 300 yards away. Its aerial agility level is IV. Every known Broom of Flying reported has the name “Hazel” engraved upon the handle.'

column20:
'(C)
These candles come in 9 different types
column21: each specific to an alignment. Any individual within 30 ft of a burning candle of like alignment is at +2 to hit and saving throws. A cleric of like alignment to a candle of invocation will determine the number of divine spells knowable as if he or she were 2 levels higher
column22: if he or she burns the candle immediately prior to his or her daily meditation. He or she will even be granted and use spells of the higher level
column23:
although these spells are usable only so long as the candle is burning. The candle of invocation normally burns for about 4 hours.

The candle can also be used to cast a gate spell and the being responding will be of the same alignment as the candle. When casting gate the candle is completely and instantly consumed. The candle can be blown out as easily as any ordinary candle. Thus
column24: the user may sometimes place the candle in a lantern to protect the flame-this does not interfere in any way with the magical effects.'

'(CP)
When burned
column21: this pure white candle creates a zone of truthfulness in a 5 ft radius around the candle for 1 hour. Within this zone any question put to a creature must be truthfully answered. A saving throw vs spells (unlisted categories) is allowed. The candle burns for 1 hour but if extinguished before that time the effects are dispelled and the candle’s magic is ruined.'

column20:
'(AT)
This brightly coloured (some might say gaudy) cape allows the wearer to cast dimension door upon him- or herself once per day
column21: disappearing in a cloud of smoke and arriving the same way at his or her new location.'
'<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td

column23: and is activated by speaking the command word. The owner need only be within voice range to activate the rug and it may be controlled with spoken directions. There are 3 common sizes of rugs (see table

column25:

column20:
'(DM)
A 6 in wide
column21: 1 in high golden vessel. When filled with incense and lit
column22: chanting the words of summoning for 1 round causes a 12 HD air elemental to appear as if summoned by a conjure elemental spell. If incense of meditation is used the air elemental will be of 16 HD. Only one elemental may be summoned at a time and another cannot be called until the first is slain
column23: dispelled
column24: or dismissed.'

column20:
'(any)
The loud
column21: clear sound of this instrument prevents any spell requiring a verbal component from being cast within 30 ft unless a saving throw vs wands is made. The chiming sound lasts for 3 full minutes and the chime of interruption can be struck once every 10 minutes.'

column20:
'(any)
Striking this magical chime causes whatever it is pointed at to open. The sound of the chime of opening affects all doors
column21: lids
column22: locks
column23: portals
column24: and valves. The magic of the chime will even dispel a hold portal or wizard lock if cast by a magic user below 15th level. It should be noted the device only affects 1 form of locking per use
column25: so a locked door with a hold portal cast upon it will require 2 soundings of the chime. A silence 15 ft radius spell will render the device useless for the duration of the spell. A new chime of opening comes with 10 uses; the chime cracks in half with the last use.'

column21:
'(M)
An elaborate golden headband with a large red ruby set in the middle. Once per day the ruby can emit a 60 ft beam of searing light which causes 40 points of damage. The circlet and the ruby are tuned to each other; removing the ruby destroys the magic.'

'(M)
A simple golden headband with a small red ruby set in the middle. Once per day the ruby can emit a 60 ft beam of searing light that causes 3d8 points of damage. The circlet and the ruby are tuned to each other; removing the ruby destroys the magic.'

column20:
'(any)
An ornate silver headband which increases the wearer’s charisma by +3 while worn.'

'(any)
A black garment of silk
column21: woven in patterns reminiscent of spider webs. This magic cloak grants the wearer immunity to entrapment by mundane or magical webs
column22: allows movement at half speed through any webbed area
column23: and allows the owner to cast web as a 10th level magic user once per day. The cloak also allows the user to spider climb as per the spell up to 10 rounds cumulative per day. Finally
column24: the wearer of the cloak of arachnida gains a +2 bonus on all saves vs spider poisons.'

column20:
'(any)
This black or dark brown cloth robe allows the user to fly for up to 7 minutes
column21: followed by a like number of minutes resting during which the cloak recharges itself. The cloak of the bat actually allows flying in 2 different modes
column22: but both require darkness or a near lightless environment in which to operate. The wearer can fly by actually polymorphing into a regular bat (aerial agility level V)
column23: or he or she can grab the edges of the garment and spread his or her arms like bat-wings. The wearer of the cloak also gains the ability to hang upside down from the ceiling like a bat
column24: and the cloak grants a 20% bonus to hide in shadows checks.'

column20:
'(any)
A finely-made cloak suitable for a lord or lady
column21: this garment enhances the wearer’s charisma by +2.'

'(any)
This cloak blurs the wearer’s outline. The cloak can be used in this manner up to a cumulative 15 rounds per day
column22: divided as the wearer chooses. While the blurring effect is in operation
column23: all physical attacks against the cloak’s wearer are at -4 and he or she gains +2 on saving throws vs magic.'

column21:
'(any)
As the major cloak of displacement
column22: except the effect is continual and defence bonuses are halved: physical attacks are at -2 and saves are at +1.'

column20:
'(any)
This neutral grey or green cloak appears normal until the hood is drawn up over the head. At that point the wearer becomes 100% invisible in natural outdoor settings
column21: with effectiveness decreasing as natural growth decreases
column22: down to about 95% in open fields. In most darkness or low light conditions in non-natural settings invisibility is still quite good
column23: around 90% for dark urban settings and 95% for torch lit or dungeon settings. A wearer attempting to move stealthily in a brightly-lit area still gains 50% invisibility. 90% of these cloaks are sized for elf-size to man-size wearers. The remaining 10% are sized for halfling sized creatures (about 4 ft tall). This item requires careful adjudication by the GM.'

column20:
'(any)
This garment has a silvery-grey sheen to it and catches the light in a curious manner. Upon uttering the command word the wearer becomes æthereal for up to 10 rounds per day. The total time can be divided up among multiple uses as the wearer sees fit.'

'(any)
A magical garment which appears as an ordinary leather cloak until the wearer enters salt water. At that time the cloak adheres to the wearer
column21:
making him or her 90% identical in appearance to a manta ray.

The cloak’s owner is AC 6 but gains any AC bonuses from magic items or magic armour he or she wears
column22: and he or she can release his or her arms from the cloak to attack normally with carried weapons. The wearer also gains the ability to breathe underwater and a swimming speed of 60 ft
column23: plus an extra tail-spine attack for 1d6 points of damage.'

column21:
th{padding: 3px}(IM)
This magic crystal sphere of about 6 in diameter allows the user to see over any distance and even into other planes. The more well known to the user the person or place sought is
column22: the higher the chance of success. Some crystal balls grant additional powers (see table
column23:
below). This item requires careful adjudication by the GM.
d%Crystal Ball Additional Abilities
01-75None
76-85Clairaudience
86-90See Invisibility
91-95ESP
96-00True Seeing
'

column20: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column21:
th{padding: 3px}(any)
This item appears as a normal sized six-sided die of ancient yellowed ivory
column22: or carved bone
column23: or any one of a number of hard minerals. The cube projects a square wall of force 10 ft on a side around the user
column24: moving with him and rendering him impervious to a specific type of attack. The cube of force has 36 charges and recharges itself at midnight every 24 hours
column25: though there have been rumours of some cubes recharging at noon. Each face of the cube generates a different type of force wall
column26: each power uses charges at a different rate
column27:
and each wall limits movement of the user to a degree; consult the first following table.

When the cube is active
column28: attacks causing excessive damage sap charges from it at a higher rate: damage in excess of 30 points in one attack burns off 1 charge for every 10 points of damage over 30. Certain spells or magic items also drain off extra charges from the cube
column29:
see second following table.
# PipsCharges/minuteMax. MovementEffect
1130 ftKeeps out gas
column31: smoke
column32:
etc.2220 ftKeeps out non-living matter3315 ftKeeps out living matter4410 ftKeeps out magic5610 ftKeeps out everything60—Deactivates
AttackExtra Charges Used
Horn of Blasting6
Wall of Fire2
Passwall3
Disintegrate6
Phase Door5
Prismatic Spray7
'

column20:
'(any)
A crystalline but featureless cube about 3⁄4 in square. Activating this device creases a cube-shaped wall of force with 10 ft sides centred around the user and moving with him or her unless he or she places the device on a surface after activation. The temperature inside the cube is always 65°F no matter the surroundings
column21: and the force wall absorbs all cold based attacks
column22: whether natural or magical. If the field absorbs more than 50 total points of cold based damage in 1 round the force wall collapses and the cube cannot be reactivated for a period of 1 hour. Additionally
column23: if the cube of frost resistance absorbs more than 100 points of cold damage in 10 rounds it is destroyed.'

column20:
'(CDIM)
This 3⁄4 in square magic item is a six-sided die of the finest carnelian and adorned with gold inlaid pips. Each of the sides of the Cubic Gate can be activated by pressing it
column21: opening a gate to random point on a specific plane. Side #1 of the cube is always keyed to the Prime Material Plane
column22: the other sides will be assigned or randomly generated by the GM. Any time a gate is opened to any plane besides the Prime Material
column23: there is a non-cumulative 10% chance per round a denizen of that plane sees the gate and comes through to investigate
column24: and depending upon the plane contacted
column25: such creatures will rarely have a favourable reaction to the PCs. Pressing a cube side twice in rapid succession will instantly transport the user and all creatures adjacent to him to a random point on the plane to which that side is keyed. Unwilling beings gain a saving throw vs petrifaction to avoid this plane-shift.'

column20:
'(C)
This likeness of a human skull is artfully and cunningly carved from a block of darkest ebony
column21: and it is unrelentingly and entirely evil. The presence of the Dark Skull makes any site
column22: building
column23:
or structure an unholy site and gains 3 major effects in a 40 ft radius around the skull.

First
column24: the structure or site is guarded by a magic circle of protection from good (as the 1st level cleric spell). Next
column25: all turning attempts by good aligned or neutral characters within the structure or site are made at -4
column26: while evil characters gain a +4 bonus to their own turning attempts. Magic resistance does not apply to this effect. Third
column27: the user of the skull may choose to fix a single spell effect to the unhallowed site. Regardless of the normal parameters for the spell
column28:
this usage will last for 1 full year and will be effective throughout the entire site or structure.

The user can further designate whether the spell effects will apply to all creatures or creatures of a particular faith or alignment. Though the spell effects lapse after 1 year
column29: they are quickly and easily renewed using the Dark Skull
column30: often as part of an unholy annual ritual. Commonly favoured spells for binding include: cause blindness
column31: chant
column34: know alignment
column35:
and true seeing; though the choice is up to the user. Saving throws and magic resistance apply normally for these fixed spells.

The skull will negate but not dispel a hallowed site with its presence; removing the Dark Skull will restore a holy place to its rightful status. Only one Dark Skull may operate in an area at any given time.'

column20:
'(any)
A leathern flask of ordinary workmanship and appearance. When the user removes the stopper and speaks the proper command word
column21: often inscribed on the bottom of the flask
column22: the decanter produces fresh or salt water in various volumes and at different velocities
column23:
with separate command words for each. A command word also stops water flow.
  • Stream: Pours 1 gallon per round.
  • Fountain: Emits a 5 ft long stream of water flowing at 5 gallons per round.
  • Geyser: Emits a 20 ft long
column24:
1 ft wide blast of water flowing at 30 gallons per round.
The geyser function creates considerable back pressure and a character with unsteady or precarious footing may be knocked to the ground. Geyser creates enough force with its blast of water to inflict 1d4 points of damage to a target within the 20 ft range but only one creature per round may be targeted.'

column20: '<style type=text/css>table {border-style: solid; border-width: 1px;} td
column21:
th{padding: 3px}(any)
A set of 34 parchment cards often found in a leather bag or wooden box. Drawing a card from the deck and casting it to the ground creates a convincing illusion of a creature or creatures. The illusion lasts until dispelled or the card is picked up; in both cases the card becomes blank and cannot be used again. The illusory monster moves and acts as if real and obeys the will of the card drawer
column22: though it cannot move more than 30 ft away from the card. A randomly-generated deck has a 90% chance of being complete
column23: otherwise 1d20 cards are missing from the deck. A table is provided below with values for both mundane playing cards and tarot cards
column24:
and the illusion the card will generate when used.
Playing CardTarot CardCreature(s)
Ace of HeartsIV. The EmperorRed Dragon
